We were expecting a welcome drink upon our arrival when exiting the vehicle, like we did at Dreams, but instead had to chase down a waiter that was walking aimlessly around the lobby with the signature drink. There were fresh moist towels behind the front desk that once again we were expecting to be handed upon check in (like Dreams) but they just sat there and never got offered to any guests. They must be for the Front Desk staff and Bellmen to use throughout their long exhausting day. All over the resort the service was non-existent unless you tipped heavily. We booked the Endless Luxury All-Inclusive plan for the value and convenience it offered and it clearly states on your website that service tips and taxes are included. We definitely are not against tipping when the service warrants it and in fact tipped heavily on our Dreams vacation, but at Hacienda Tres Rios we consistently got our own drinks and food no matter if we were at the pool or on the beach. In our book tips are earned, not expected! Service was consistently slow or non-existent in the outlets as well. One incident I remember vividly was during breakfast at the Casa Las Islas buffet at 8am when the restaurant was not even half full we were seated and waited 10 minutes without any servers approaching us. After getting frustrated, I proceeded to get up and pour my husband and me our own coffee and my own mimosa. When the server did arrive he didn’t look surprised at all and didn’t even apologize for the wait or lack of service. We had another disappointing encounter in the Mexican restaurant, El Alebrije on our last evening. We arrived at 6:30pm when the restaurant opened and there were only 4 other tables occupied by resort guests. We were seated and waited 15 minutes to even be approached by any servers to give us water and take our drink order. We finally ordered our three course dinner at 7pm, an appetizer, Soup and Main Entrée. Our first course arrived 45 minutes later and was to be a hot appetizer and it was ice cold. Our second course was skipped completely (not at our request) perhaps it was just too much for them to handle. When the main course finally arrived the veal was overcooked, crispy and cold as well. At this point we left the restaurant and told the hostess of our disappointment. An hour later, we received a call from the Restaurant Manager apologizing and offering us a free dinner! Did you get that, A FREE DINNER . . . remember we booked an Endless Luxury All-Inclusive plan, how generous of him! Perhaps he could have taken a little time to research our reservation and not have made such a ridiculous offer to us the evening prior to our departure. All around the food was mediocre at best and honestly we get better Mexican food locally here in Colorado. However, we did have one spectacular dinner at the Porto Bello Italian restaurant. The service was good, the waiter was pleasant and the food was delicious. Unfortunately, it couldn’t make up for the other unfortunate dinning experiences. The guest room halls were always littered with room service dishes and we often would see the same dishes in the halls for up to 24 hours. We had to get our own amenities from the housekeeping carts since they are strictly one use each due to their small size and the housekeeper did not replace daily. Our room was consistently not made-up until at least 4pm and one evening we came back from a day at the pool, showered, changed for dinner and had to go to the front desk at 6:30pm and request our room be cleaned. There was always a moldy stench in the air that we could not get rid of, and clothes never really dried due to the humidity. All of our clothes returned home with a horrible smell . It was just an all around disappointing trip. Perhaps the part that truly upsets me the most is during the wedding reception we attended, I glanced up to notice the Bride cutting her own wedding cake while the servers stood at the bar chatting. Please tell me this is not your policy. I am a Wedding Coordinator myself and was appalled at this site. I quickly took charge and cut and plated the cake as your servers ever so graciously held out plates for me – seriously? I finally put the knife down and politely asked they finish with serving the cake. I am from a Hospitality background of over 15 years and perhaps this is the reason I am so critical of service and attention to detail. Perhaps, we were unlucky and just caught your staff on a bad week, or maybe you were short staffed due to illness. I don’t feel these to be true, but I do sincerely believe your hotel has some serious service issues and your employees need to be reprogrammed that no matter what kind of tips come their way (if any) each and every guest deserves to be treated equally, their needs met, and more importantly exceed all expectations! Being a Wedding Coordinator I frequently have brides that are looking for destination weddings and I am positive that Hacienda Tres Rios will not be one that they choose. I wish your property success in the future!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, friendly staff, relaxed elegance”
Reviews.Author: KTSunny
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Hacienda Tres Rios from Nov. 13 – Nov. 20. This was our first stay here, actually first stay at any resort associated with Sunset resorts, though we first purchased in 2002. That year we also bought into Palace Resorts, and have stayed at several of their resorts through the years, mainly because we spent more and had more incentives to use Palace. We first made our reservation last March and had decided to stay at the Royal Sunset on the beach in the hotel zone. A couple months after making the reservation and paying for our week, we were informed that Royal Sunset would be closed for renovations during the week of our vacation. We were offered a stay at either the Sunset Lagoon or Hacienda Tres Rios. We chose the latter since it was so new, and we weren’t disappointed! We had requested an ocean view and a king size bed, but ended up with the view and 2 double beds. We called and requested a different room and were told that there wouldn’t be any available until Monday, and that we would be moved at that point. However, after sleeping on the double bed, it was so very comfortable that we let them know the following day that we would keep the original room. I have a problem with hard, “too firm” beds, but their beds are great – fluffy feather beds on top of the mattress just lulled me to sleep. Also, the room didn’t have the 2 person Jacuzzi that some rooms did, it had a sofa instead. This was fine with us as we are not huge fans of the Jacuzzi that Palace Resorts include in their rooms. We thought the sofa was a far more usable feature! The rooms are very comfortable with a table and chairs and a balcony with tables and chairs as well. There is a small refrig that is restocked daily, and the bathroom is well arranged with a separate little room with the toilet – a huge walk in shower and a sink and large mirror and vanity in between. There is a coffee maker and real cups, saucers and spoons. They do supply terry robes for each person. There is 24-hour room service, but we didn’t use it, so can’t comment on it. When you first check in, you are introduced to your personal “concierge”. This person, ours was Tatiana, sits down with you and explains how things work. She told us the days that the Italian and Asian restaurants were open and that if we wanted to eat there we would need to make reservations the day before by 3:00 p.m. She also briefly went through the “tours” they offer (which are right on the grounds and include visiting their nursery, biking, snorkeling in their cenote, and/or kayaking in their rivers). She mentioned that we each were entitled to a lobster dinner at the restaurant of our choice, and a 30 minute massage (you need to pay the tax of $12 for this). She gave us the times of the daily (Monday – Friday) complementary van to and from Playa del Carmen and told us about the other tours that for members are 50% of the stated price. She then invited us to the sales presentation, to “learn what is new about our membership”. For going to this, she offered to make one of our massages a 50 minute one with no tax charge and give us tickets to the Thursday evening dinner and horse show. We agreed to attend, and were told that it would be Sunday morning and would begin with breakfast upstairs in the Mexican restaurant that is not open for breakfast except for the sales events. I know that many people have complained about how awful the sales presentations are, but I guess I need to say it wasn’t so bad. Since we are owners at another “vacation club” in Mexico and multiple timeshares in the U.S., we are used to the idea of these updates, and have come to see the time as a way to find out what is going on and what is offered. They of course would like to take all your other timeshares in “trade” and have you “upgrade”. They were surprised at how cheaply we got into the system – again the time we purchased, we had already bought into Palace and just kept saying “no”, until it got so cheap that we gave in. We listened to all they had to say and then simply said that we liked all our timeshares, enjoyed the variety, and were not interested in upgrading. The representative was disappointed, but polite, and we got our “gifts” and parted amicably. I also have read reviews complaining about everything, from the food to the service and frankly, those who complain about this place I believe won’t be happy anywhere! We found the staff friendly and helpful and everything, everywhere spotlessly clean! The food was for the most part, excellent!. The only meal that we found just average was the first night. We ate dinner in Casa la Islas, the buffet restaurant, and the food again was average, as seems to be for buffets. The same place for breakfast was excellent, with custom made omelets, tasty side dishes, wonderful juices, fruits, breads, and pastries and friendly and helpful waiters. Dinner in the Italian restaurant was really good and also, we loved the steaks for dinner at the Hacienda Grill. Some people we talked to believed that the Grill – which doubles as the pool bar and restaurant during the day – was closed for dinner. Not true – they have a different menu, still serve the same great drinks and also wine with your meal. This was our favorite dinner restaurant. We had our lobster dinner at the Mexican restaurant ,and the lobster dinner is a set menu that is the same where ever you have it. The dinner menu at the Mexican restaurant looked really good, and we intended to get back there, but for some reason never did. On Sunday night they held a welcome Mexican fiesta with a great buffet, toasts of tequila when you first got there and unlimited drinks. We didn’t get to the Asian restaurant as we first planned to go there on Thursday night, but then instead went to the dinner/horse show instead. With the fact that certain restaurants are only open certain nights, you really need to plan things out ahead of time. Usually when on vacation, we sleep in and then eat only 2 meals, a large breakfast and dinner. However, since we wanted to try lunch at the Pizza place by the pool, one day we just had fruit and pastries for breakfast and then pizza for lunch. Another “don’t miss”. There is a menu, but you can basically just tell them what you want on your pizza and they make it, cook it in the brick oven, and serve with your choice of drink, really great! E.g., pepperoni is not on any menu items, but it is available if requested. About the dinner/horse show – don’t miss it! Whether you go to the sales presentation and get it as a gift, or you pay for it, just go. Unfortunately for us, Thursday was the only day it rained – and it poured! We thought they might cancel it, but they didn’t. It is quite a ride – you go into Cancun and then turn off some road and go to the “Equestrian Center”. It is a large stable, with a large capacity to serve food, drinks, and entertainment. Normally you would eat outdoors and enjoy the entertainment following dinner. We ate indoors and then heard by word of mouth that we would simply eat and go back to the resort. We happened to be eating with a really nice Canadian couple we had met, and they said that in their van, they had been the only passengers, and if it stopped raining, they planned to stay for the show and invited us to ride back with them. So, we all went outside – up the stairs, past horses in their stalls to a large deck set up with tables and chairs, more food, enthusiastic and friendly drink servers and a stage show. And – it wasn’t raining! So – we found our original van driver, who had the others in the van and was frantically looking for us. We told him we were staying for the show. The next day we found that others in the van would have preferred to stay as well. I think there was a bit of confusion going on. Anyway, the stage show had a lot of singing and dancing and costumes and was great. Then we went down to the arena to see the horse show. They gave us cushions to sit on (so you wouldn’t get wet), and we began to watch the show. The rain began to pick up, and so we decided after the act to leave – everyone had the same idea. They directed us to a different part of the seating area that had a roof. So, we sat down again and saw a beautiful little girl – maybe 10 years old – riding a horse and singing like an angel. She sang as her horse made dressage moves, and it was enchanting! Then the rain picked up, and it began pouring and still the girl sang her heart out and finished her act. After that, it was raining continually, so we left. But, I’m sure if not for the rain, the rest of the show would be well worth going! One day we took the Tigrillo tour. They take you on sort of a “train” pulled by a jeep and first you go to their nursery and hear about their efforts to grow various tropical plants used on the grounds. Then you go to their cenote, where everyone puts on a life preserver. If you want to snorkel, they will give you a mask and snorkel, and you can jump into the cenote. Evidently some people actually snorkel down the river to where it goes into the Gulf, but everyone in our group opted for a 10 minute snorkel and then got into kayaks. The kayaking was a very easy trip of maybe 10-15 minutes through a canopy of trees and bushes. The whole trip took about 1.5 hours, and we had a fun group of people. As others have reported, the beach right in front of the resort is not great as the river water mixing with the Gulf. The water looks a bit brown, but you can walk down the shore a bit and find very nice and inviting areas to swim. Twice we took the free van into Playa del Carmen. They will either drop you off on 5th Ave for shopping, or take you to their sister resort, the Sunset Fisherman. The first time, we had them drop us off at their closest point to the ferry dock and took the ferry to Cozumel and went SCUBA diving for the afternoon. Since the last van returning to Tres Rios leaves at 5:00, and we took the 6:00 ferry from Cozumel, we needed to take a taxi back – with tip it was $20. If you ferry to Cozumel, buy 1-way tickets. There are two ferry operators, each running every other hour, and a roundtrip ticket forces you to one operator’s schedule, perhaps making you wait an extra hour for that ferry operator. While they are scheduled to leave every hour on the hour, they seem to leave about 10 minutes late. The second time we used the transportation to Playa, we went to the Sunset Fisherman Resort. We took the 9:30 van there and the 2:00 van back. That resort is older, much smaller, but is right on a beautiful beach. If you have experienced the very small stretch of sandy beach in Playa del Carmen in the past – you need to check out their great job of rehabbing the beach! It is now a wide area of beautiful white sand, just outstanding. Anyway, while there, you can use the beach, pool, lounges, etc. and can also have drinks and/or lunch there. You can also walk down the beach till you get to the ferry dock and then walk around the shopping area there. A really nice way to spend the day! Something that is offered, though not stressed nearly enough is their “Sensory Adventure”. This is really different and involves a short walk into the jungle, where you close your eyes, put on blind folds and are led along and through things and experience different smells, sounds, sensations. I’m not going to describe any more, as I don’t want to ruin the adventure, but it was very different than anything we had experienced and kind of “mind broadening”. Don’t miss it! If there is a problem with Hacienda Tres Rios, I believe it lies in their communications. I think they just haven’t figured out how to help people get the most out of their weeks’ stay, so with that idea in mind, here are my suggestions. • When you first arrive, plan out your week, considering what days different restaurants are open, when you may want to do the sensory adventure, tours, go to Playa del Carmen, etc. • Go to the Concierge desk – there will be one person sitting behind the sign Concierge. There will always be others sitting there, who may or may not ask if they can help, but wait until you can sit down and make your reservations. • Though you can make reservations as you go along, many times the vans going to Playa del Carmen (holds only 10 guests) may be full at the time you want to go or come back, so if you can make your reservations – both ways. You can always get a cab (about $14) but free is better. • Again, each couple is entitled to one lobster dinner. It can be served at any restaurant, but you must let them know a day ahead of time. • Our Concierge originally told us we were each to get a 30 minute massage and said that there would be two people at a certain desk in the lobby that could help us with that. When we tried that, we were told we needed to talk to our original Concierge, who wasn’t there that day. What we found is if you go directly to the Spa – down the hall past the Sports bar and dessert place/business center, past the car rental desk and then up one flight, you can make your massage appointments. • When you want a drink during the day, the best plan is to walk over to the Hacienda Grill by the pool. If you are sitting by the pool, they will bring your drinks to you. • On the terrace outside Casa la Islas, they often have ethnic food demonstrations, so check the calendar for times and subjects. • Wi Fi service works well some times in your room. If you are having a problem, it always works in the lobby, and there are two computers in the business center that you can use. • They really don’t want you to feed the animals, but there are 3 coatis, cute animals about the size of a raccoon, with long brown tails that sit up and beg, and many people feed them fruit. • Don’t expect American efficiency; this is Mexico, and you are on vacation – smile and say “Hola” to everyone and relax. You will have a great time!

Reviews.Title: “Forget the bad reviews - this place is not perfect but still awesome”
Reviews.Author: CDR37
Reviews.Content: Let me first start off by saying that I had a lot of apprehension about staying at this resort after I had paid for my entire 10 day stay at Tres Rios in advance. We travelled from January 2 to 12, 2010. The negative reviews of that time had to do with time share sales, the beach, and the food. Though it has been a few months, I remember the trip like it was yesterday and will share my experience. We arrived in Mexico after taking a connection on US Airways through Phoenix. Immigration was smooth. Duty free was lined up and was very slow so it is better to avoid that store until you are back at the airport for your return trip. We took the luggage on the free baggage carts and proceeded towards the exit. There are about 15 men who block the corridor leading to the exit. They have official looking badges saying something to the effect that they are Cancun transportation authority staff. One of them took us to a table, asked us if we needed transportation (I had arranged a private van in advance over the Internet) and then proceeded to try to pitch us on free tickets we could receive if we attended a time share presentation. At that point I said No thanks, grabbed my cart and headed for the door. Outside our driver was waiting with my name on a card and we made it to the hotel in about 30 minutes. Cost to the resort for a private shuttle was $50 each way. Well worth it over a share shuttle as you do not have to travel to many hotels as other people get dropped off first. I learned this the hard way in Hawaii. Once off the main highway, there is about a 1KM road through the jungle to the resort. We arrived at night and it was very cool to see the roadside lights leading a path to the resort. We checked in very quickly and made our way to our 3rd floor ocean view suite that had a king bed. Bed bugs were never a problem, nor mosquitos or any other bugs for that matter at any time during our stay. The only wildlife we saw was a raccoon who used to sneak around the outdoor Pizzeria from time to time. We nicknamed him Ricky, a name the staff loved. The next morning we awoke to a beautiful sunrise and a view that is really amazing. Well kept grounds and pools and the ocean as a backdrop. The room was very modern which is what we expected for a one year old hotel. The furniture was high end expresso, a nice couch and table with chairs, and LCD television, lots of storage space, a nice new mattress and lots of pillows. The bathroom was very nice with a 4x8 tile walk in shower, and a private room for a toilet. The safe in the closet worked well and we never had a problem with theft. The room was very spacious and about twice the size of a typical North American hotel room. Maid service was excellent and the sheets, towels, and garbage were changed each day. Our first meal was the buffet breakfast which was not a four seasons buffet but better than most. The people who stay here come from many different nationalities, so they try to serve food that meets everyone's tastes. As this resort was rated the top all-inclusive in Central America, we saw many rich and likely famous Mexican and Latin families eating around us. It is the place to travel to if you are among the elite in Mexico. A Mexican movie star was also there but as I do not watch Spanish movies I wouldn't have been able to pick him out of a police line-up. The breakfast was very good in that they have an omelette/waffle/cooked-to-order egg chef and a large variety of fruit and other items like hashbrowns and meats such as bacon. They also had a large selection of breads, pastries, and my favorite - croissants which were fresh. There was never a shortage of food or tables and we were eating within minutes of arrving each morning. The fresh orange and pineapple juice were also good. This is a very quiet resort and not the place to party. The sports bar is family orientated and more of a place to grab a drink if you are inside than anything else. On one day it rained and they had games planned in this lounge for families which included a pool table contest, a music trivia contest, and other types of games. Outside, there were a lot of lounge chairs to be had and we had our favorite place to sit everyday. We tried the beds on the beach one day and they were taken most of the time but very few chair hogs were at the resort. One group of three young ladies had put two towels on two beds and then proceeded to lie on chairs on the beach. This got me going so I asked them if they were using the beds. They said yes and then made a lame attempt to use one of the beds. I then took one of the towels off the second bed and threw it on their first bed. These chair cows as they were now labelled were the exception at the resort rather than the rule you often hear about at other resorts. As you have to sign in and out your beach towels at the outdoor cafe, people do not leave them lying around on chairs saving a spot for the whole day. We were there in January and the pool was on the chillier side, likely because the temperature drops off at night to the high 60s. It would take me about a minute to get used to the water but once I did I was fine. Most people I watched would dip their toe and then never go in so I had the pool to myself many times. The few I convinced to jump in were fine once they got used to it and would stay in the pool for hours. The few children that were at the pools also did not seem to have a problem with the temperature of the pool as they would play on floating toys for hours. Most were well behaved which was a reflection of their parents and the ambiance of the resort. This was not a McDonalds playland by any means. We did see the kids club group walking around and it looked like the kids where having fun doing what they were doing (crafts, ..) The beach is not the reason to go to this resort. The sand and beach chair are fine but the water not so much. The reason the water is murky is that the fresh water from the cenotes empties into the ocean creating a mixture that is a little briny. While we are not tree huggers we respected what the hotel was doing environmentally and accepted this natural occurance. We did travel to Playa Del Carmen once or twice to sit on the main beach and swim in the turqoise blue water which is picture perfect. That and you can get a massage for $20 an hour near the beach there which my wife took up. We did not do any of the hotel tours around the resort (scent tour, jaguar tour, ...) but we did take the two person kayak out on our own and travelled up the cenote. That was fun as you have to navigate through mangroves to finally get to a dock with a swimming hole. The water is crystal clear and it is fresh water which I prefer to salt water anyway. It was very refreshing. Speaking of saltwater, the pools are all salt water pools so you don't get that chlorine smell in your hair and swim suits. This was very popular in the Red Sea resorts we have stayed at so it was nice to see it adopted here as well. At night they have a show that varies. One night a musician, one night a fire dance show, ... We watched most from our balcony as it has nice chairs that you can sit and relax on. The front desk and concierge staff was excellent. They have a room full of DVDs that you can rent for free. You pick a box, take it to the concierge, and he asks you to sign it out and gives you the DVD which you return the next day. This was a favorite thing to do after dinner as there is no night life and no parties. For lunch they have an outdoor pizzeria which makes pan pizzas that have very fresh toppings. More european style than Pizza hut style, but a nice change. The main place to eat at lunch is the outdoor grill which has an excellent seletion of well presented and prepared foods. My favorites were the jumbo BBQ prawns on rice and the fresh baked tortilla chips and salsa. All the food is prepared on the outdoor grill so it is fresh. In terms of drinks, we never had a problem with poolside service. Often times I was given a new drink before I had even finished the previous one. Want a tip that will work for you in any country you travel to (and I have been to many). Tip both the waiter and bartender on the second day. If you tip on the first day they will expect it everyday. When you tip on the second you thank them for the excellent service the day before, ask them there name, introduce yourself, and give them a nice tip ($10 - $20) for their service the day before. At that point you become their best friend. Yes you paid for an all-inclusive trip but this will put you ahead of everybody else and get you top shelf all the time. By the end of the ten days I had a beverage waiting even before I walked up to say hello. The service was friendly, efficient, and they covered all areas outdoors, from the beach to the pools to the couches near the hotel doors. The food at night was the highlight. I am not sure what world other people live in but having eaten at some of the best hotels and on the best cruise ships in the world, this was up to that standard. It was truly five star. Well presented, always hot, and with sauces and seasonings to die for. Whether it was fish, chicken, steak, or sushi, it was excellent. The deserts were also incredible. Dinner was a highlight to the end of each day. We never ate at the buffet at night so I cannot comment on the food there. One night when the restaurent was at capacity we sat in the buffet area and ordered off the same menu as the restaurent. That was a nice bonus. There were two restaurents open when we were there, not including the buffet area. The spanish restaurent was open every day and served traditional spanish food. Then the main floor restaurent alternated between Italian and Japanese on alternate nights, with the menu changing each time. You can stay two weeks and never eat the same thing twice if you want as the menu is quite varied. They have appetizers, soups, salads, main courses, and desserts each day as well as a chef's special. We also did room service two nights and the quality was as good as the restaurent, though the menu was a little more basic and what you would normally get back home. The clam chowder in a bread bowl was great, as was the steak sandwich. Our room had 2-two litre bottles of water provided each day which we did not use unless we were in the room. The water at the restaurents and pool was fine and we did not get any type of stomach upset while we were there. That is mostly due to the on-site filtration plant the hotel has. In the room we used the ice from the machines as well as the bottled water. All was fine. The only negatives I had during the vacation was renting a car from the on-site vendor and being paranoid of the time share person finding us. First the car story. We wanted to rent a car for two days to check out the Costco in Cancun as well as travel to Chitzen-itcha where the pyramids were. I went downstairs to talk to the rep and he quoted me 80 bucks a day. I went back to my room to use my netbook (the free wireless internet works great in the rooms, around the pool, and even out to the beds on the beach) and booked with the same company on-line and called the company to confirm the car we wanted for $30 and that I could pick it up at the hotel where they had a branch. An hour later I went to the desk and the man there said he was busy and to come back in 30 minutes. When i came back, he could not find the reservation and that the car we wanted had just been rented. In its place he had a compact beater which was rusting out. He then had the gall to start negotiating price with me. Rather than waste a day, we rented it for $50 per day and then I almost lost it when the rental boy starting marking down every scratch on the windshield and body. The car might have been worth $500 bucks back home. I told him that if they tried to charge me a penny for any damage on this rust bucket, I would see that they were tossed out of the hotel. So we rented the car for two days and on return found that the price on the invoice was back to the $79 and they would not negotiate. At this point I lost it and it took everything in my power not to beat the guy across the desk. Instead I went to the front desk and they calmed me down with a couple of vouchers for a massage. If you do decide to rent a car, do not use these rounders. Instead catch the $12 taxi into Cancun where they have reputable car rental outlets. In terms of the time share folks, I had read a lot on this site about the sales people. We were never visited by them when we were outside by the pool but we could see them in the lobby so you never wanted to sit in the lobby for fear of being approached. We also had a person call us once each day to give us our orientation package and I never would call them back. Finally, I told the front desk to have them stop calling each day as I was hear for a vacation and if I wanted to buy a time share I would contact them on my own. In retrospect, I should have just did the five minute orientation and said no when they asked if I wanted to learn more about the resort. I will do this the next time I am there as we are going back for two weeks in January. It is just too beautiful of a resort to not want to stay and eat at. I would recommend this resort to those who want peace and quiet and excellent food and service in a very secluded, safe, and natural environment. Not recommended for those who like to party or need constant activities to keep them entertained. And by all means, do not take the time share tour unless you are prepared to shell out cash for a time share. Even the strongest can get sucked in to buying something they never planned on owning in the first place. If you want a time share, this is a beautiful place to own one and the tour will be worthwhile. Just make sure to keep saying no until you ge the price you want. Otherwise skip the 4 hour presentation as many have stated on here. Hope this review is helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointment”
Reviews.Author: Dra23
Reviews.Content: We stayed here because our friends were getting married, and this is where they had their wedding activities. If we stayed any place else we would not have been able to 'hang out' other than the wedding activities, so since we didn't have much of a choice, we decided to stay here. Upon check in they had us in a king oceanview room which was fine but we requested a jacuzzi. Upon inspection of the jacuzzi suite room, we found two double beds. When we inquired about a king jacuzzi, they stated that the rooms with jacuzzis only have double beds. Which sort of confused us, but OK we settled on the king ocean view. The first morning my husband woke up with bites all over his stomach and chest. I quickly stripped the sheets to look for bed bugs. We went down to the front desk at 7:30am to ask them to change our sheets (Including the comforter) immediately. We originally were going to change rooms, but we got the 'last' king bed ocean view. We explained we were going to the spa, and would not be back until 10am, so if it could be done by then, that would be great. We arrived back in our room at 10:30am to find it just as we left it. It took them a second reminder to change everything out, and then they put the same comforter on the bed.. I called for a new one immediately and stripped the old one off the bed. The old comforter remained on the floor for the remainder of our stay (5 days). Thankfully no bugs after that. I found the food here a disappointment. The Italian resturant is the only place where I would suggest to eat. For the $185/nt per person, we paid, we did not come anywhere near that with the food due to the fact it was just poor quality. I will say the food that we had for the wedding related activites was very good. They had a welcome buffet on the beach with a bar-b-que theme which was very tasty and edible. I didn't care for the fact there was one bar on site, it was a sports bar, which is fine if you are a sports fan. They permit children in the bar, which was a bit of an inconvenience due to the fact they played with the pool table, thus leaving any adult wanting to play out of luck. There was no lounge/bar where you could just go relax have a quiet drink. We didn't like the fact that the jacuzzi's by the pool were in the 'children's pool' as well as the bar was in that area as well. So you had to make a trade off, either an easy walk to the jacuzzi and easy access to the bar, or an quieter pool. The ocean is as bad as every review states....brown..unappealing. We didn't even attempt going in. I have to say one huge plus was the spa service we recieved. The spa Director, Astrid was very pleasant and set up our appointments prior to arrival. We recieved hot stone massages, and I have to say they were the best I ever had. I am an Event Manager and I have traveled to many hotels with fancy spas, but this treatment was the best ever. I have to say the one 'upside' of the trip. All in all I would not recommend this hotel, I was disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Meh... not really worth the money”
Reviews.Author: mrputtputt
Reviews.Content: I thought for the price of the stay and the mandatory all-inclusive of $125 per person per day, it would be so worthwhile. Instead, we started our stay with pure disappointment. We got to the resort early moving from another resort the previous week. I'm OK with not getting the room until 3pm but we waited for about 4 hours. The concierge gave us the whole rundown of the place and that if we wanted to eat at the restaurants, we have to make reservations by 3pm. And boy, are they strict on that! We didn't get to our room until 330 and when we tried make the reservation, they pretty much said tough luck. I guess I'll chalk that up to experience. We also asked for a single king bed for our room and we ended up getting 2 beds instead. So another zinger there. Even though technically all the restaurants are open, not all are open simultaneously. On some days, only 2 out of 3 are open. On others only 1 of 3. And you really had to get the schedule and book early so you don't forget in case you do a tour or something. We booked for the rest of the week after the first dinner to avoid having to go back and forth and/or make calls. The computers in the room aren't always right. The menu does not change between the days they are open during the week either. We did a short presentation even if we're not planning on buying. So much marketing spiel said to promote it but it's really just another BS story in the end. They pride themselves of having in-room dining 24 hours and can get you ANYTHING you want. We tested that by asking for just desert from one of the restaurants and the in-room dining folks said it's only off their menu. Kind off odd because some other guests said the same thing, but I suspect they did not actually try it and it was hearsay or they also did a presentation. That is why I think the Sunset Group has such a bad rap among lies and scams written about them. The staff is filled with many lies. Lastly, we wanted to have a drink while just waiting for some food by the pool. The bar tender by the other pool was conducting a drinks class. OK fine even though another American gives U.S. folks a bad rap by being such an asswipe by saying "how about this for a lesson, jack and coke. And then looks at the crowd to try and get support as he's not taking a no for an answer." I go by the other out door grill and they said "use the waiters." I'm like.. I"m here? Why can't you just give me a simple lemonade and a soda? They are so understaffed and probably only have 2 total handling both pool areas. Other negatives. - we found a t-shirt under the sheets with it saying "sorry" in the front. thought it was a joke or something. but the shirt was used. We had to get the sheets changed. I'm not sure how this could happen but it did give me the hibbie jibbies. - you're locked in the resort. they do have 3 shuttles to down and pick you to bring you back. But they're not early enough if you wanted to do activities like go to Cozumel. Most of those tours usually want you at the dock like 8am. And the first shuttle does not leave until 8:30am. Taxi is $10-$20 from resort to Playa del Carmen. - If you don't buy the all-inclusive, it's VERY expensive to eat. I saw this was rated 4 stars and they got some awards for best all-inclusive. If you're familiar with Vegas, this place has nothing against Wynn, Bellagio and the Venetian. I mean.. nothing. It's over priced food that'll probably be $60-80 tops for both people sans alcoholic drinks for dinner. OK.. .maybe even $100 but that's really pushing it. There are some plusses but not much. - bed sheets are super high thread count and very comfortable. - there is a pillow service if you want different pillows of different firmness - they turn the beds during dinner time when you're out. They clean in the morning but you have to be very good on your door sign. Else, they can come knocking as early as 9am. - The beach is not as clear as most in Playacar and Playa del Carmen. Not even against Cancun. There is still another corner that has some dark crap floating around. It's not very clear water on the majority of the beach but the water is clearer on one portion on the left side. Not quite swimmable since it's shallow and quite a few reefs or rocks with lots of algae on top. - There are activities to do, but they repeat themselves daily. So again, you can be bored very quickly if you're not the sit by the pool/beach and lie down type. - We had 1 very attentive and very good waiter so far out of 3 dinners from 3 restaurants. The other 2 were just OK. - Tip is supposed to be included in the all-inclusive already, but you're still kinda guilted into giving by the concierge when we validated. I would've given anyway but just kind of sucks you are guilted into it by the concierge when they explain. I'll say if you're seasoned enough or do internet research, you can do just as well for a fraction of the price. Do searches on Sunset Fisherman, Sunset Royal, Tres Rios and you can read many horror stories on their scams on time shares selling. Now take those lies and apply them to when you're actually in the resort. It's too bad. The place is a little charming and does try. It's small compared to what they try to compete against like Mayakoba and the like.

Reviews.Title: “Don't even think about it”
Reviews.Author: lever8651
Reviews.Content: First off the bat, My wife and I and several other couples have been taking a fall vacation to the Cancun/Riviera Maya area for twelve years and haven't missed a year. So, I feel qualified to rate this resort in comparison to several others in the area. And, in fact, I felt so "taken advantage of" by Hacienda that I've waited over a week before writing this caveat and review. Now I've cooled off but I'm still disgusted with this place. 1. We paid well more than twice what we had ever paid for seven nights all-inc. 2. The food is very good but the restaurant schedule is more limited than anywhere we've ever been, partly due to the fact that the Mexican restaurant is never open for breakfast unless you're willing to sit through their time share/membership/vacation club sales presentation. There are no restaurants on the beach (I don't care what the web site says). 3. There are no bars on the beach. Beach service is pretty good -- limited number of lounges, beds and no palapas. But the drinks are very good -- better liquor than anywhere we've been all-inc. 4. Beach itself is worse than Cancun after the hurricane! Looks pretty good but a few steps into the water and there is debris all over the bottom, dead mangrove and other vegetation. They are literally trying to reclaim some of the eroded beach with trabajadors and wheel barrows, one load at a time dumped onto dead flora. 5. Now, trust me on this one; if you look at the photos on the web site you'll see the pools and you'll see what looks like one of the three rivers meandering through the manicured grounds. Well... not exactly... there are three little creek-like rivers on the property; however, what you see on the brochure is a man-made canal cut into the limestone. It does connect to what they call river number 1, circles through the grounds within the semicircle of buildings and rooms, and exits back into river number 1(rio numero uno). The hotel workers seem to be perpetually trying to vacuum up the silt from the bottom and sides of this "artificial circle" so at least half of the circle is so muddy/silty you can't see more than a few inches into the water -- and it stinks! Okay, you with me so far? Well the pristine cenote that you snorkel in and the little stream that flows -- maybe four hundred meters -- out to the sea is the same river number 1 that they draw water from and pump their trapped circle water, silt and sludge back into. If you happen to be enjoying your snorkel run down this pristine, eco park water way, it really is beautiful with Peacock Bass, Snook, Mullet, and colorful crabs until you get to where the filthy water from the inner circle is surging back into this little river. Now you can't see your own hand 12 inches in front of your mask and you'll notice that you smell like the dregs from your old aquarium that you should have cleaned out months before. Bottom line is this friends; I got dying dog sick the night after swimming/snorkling through this waste, was sick all the way home and now, after more than ten days I'm still under the weather. I'm a damn seasoned traveler, a backpacker, always carry doxycycline, and treat questionable water with iodine. Last time I was this sick was in the bush in Vietnam as a Recon Marine. My advise: don't trust Hacienda Tres Rios with your health. 6. We all thought we were hip to the time share pitches. Wrong! We got suckered in at check-in. The young concierge we were told would "brief" us on the resort and eco park and give us our armbands, actually sent us to a time share presentation (breakfast in the Mexican Restaurant) When we made it known that we were not interested, we had to almost become belligerent to get out of the room. Four different sales presenters cornered us. And we never got our armbands. We were also told -- and this is still on their website -- that guests at Tres Rios are welcome at any other Sunset Group Property. However, after a fifteen dollar cab ride into Playa to the Sunset Fisherman, we were asked for our armbands to be admitted to the property. We explained that we were not given any and would not need any. Wrong! We were not admitted; we walked back into Playa, and caught a $14 cab back to Hacienda Tres Rios. We confronted our "personal" conceriege about the situation. She checked with her supervisor who told her to tell us that the armbands and other facilities were for vacation club members only. In spite of our $1300 per person/per week we were commoners intruding on the elite. I felt like Rodney Dangerfield at the Groundhog Day Country Club -- think I've got my movies right? In all fairness to this resort, the food was great, the staff were the best we've ever been served by, the drinks are top notch, and the rooms are perfection. We had a good time, all in all. If management was the same caliber as the staff this could have been a world class facility... maybe..... Do yourselves a favor and book a place like a Sandos, go to a great restaurant in town with call brand liquor and go to a real eco park like Xelha or Xcaret. You'll be dollars ahead and better served.

Reviews.Title: “Another Great Vacation at Tres Rios as Owners”
Reviews.Author: capecodder9
Reviews.Content: We returned this year for another adventure at Tres Rios. We were very happy with the improvements from last year to this year. The beach was nicer and their were more things to do. We loved the service from our friend, Sammy, he is great. We loved the wine and tequila tastings. We like the new dinner show with the gorgeous singers and dancers!!! The fire show is always great. The only negatives were the spotty service around the pool, and the computer in our room. The computer worked one day and it was great, then never again. The staff could use more english also. As far as the sales presentations, we talked to alot of the guests and heard alot of comments about them. We are owners and attended as members update and they tried to sell us an upgrade to the new buildings. We declined and enjoyed the free massages and the rest of our vacation. We noticed that most of the negative comments about the sales presentations came from the guests that could not afford to own, not from the owners. All and all a Great vacation, we came home happy and a littl heavier, hahaha.

Reviews.Title: “As long as you stay away from the Time Share Vultures”
Reviews.Author: jdgmbi
Reviews.Content: I have mixed feelings regarding this stay. It is mixed with some real treasures and some real dudes. Miguel Sotelo in the dining room was wonderful. He took great care in selecting our meals. He is an asset to the resort. Another great addition is the young staff. Particuliarly Corey, Jennifer, and Montego in the field activity's. They were great with the kids and were very enthusiastic in their jobs. Would I recommend this place: Yes and No.

Reviews.Title: “Another fantastic visit in paradise”
Reviews.Author: CanadaWhistler
Reviews.Content: This was our second visit and we were as stunned by the service and beauty as our first visit. Sammy yet again was the man and looked after us again. All the staff make this place a truly amazing place to stay. Angel, Justino and all the other servers, Carlos, Osiris and the memory makers team make it a highly recommended resort to stay. Not to forget the rest of the staff unnamed who work to make the dreams and memories possible. See you next year. Joe and Jo

Reviews.Title: “Great place to own and stay”
Reviews.Author: bonniestanley
Reviews.Content: Bought a timeshare there. It's really great. Private, romantic, quiet, very nice. Service is excellent... Food is good. Cabanas to sleep overnight on the beach. A few pools - a river that ran right under our balcony, the jungle on the other side, and the ocean across from the river. The best of all worlds..

Reviews.Title: “An amazing and excellent place to stay in. no (-) A+++++”
Reviews.Author: Peterp7777
Reviews.Content: Amazing place, entertainment, kids club amazing! takes care of kids profesionaly. can not say any bad word.

Reviews.Title: “Delightful Week at Hacienda Tres Rios”
Reviews.Author: RexInTulsa
Reviews.Content: My wife and I visited the Hacienda Tres Rios resort from May 21 to May 28, 2010. What a delightful trip. Our check in went very quickly. The time share was mentioned by the young lady checking us in, but that was the end of that. We wore no bracelets during our week there and we really couldn’t figure out why that was. We saw several people wearing bracelets and they had at least 4 or 5 different colors. The room we had was at the bottom of the U-Shaped resort on the third floor so we looked out on the pool area towards the beach and we could even see Cozumel most days. It was a very beautiful sight from our balcony looking out over the resort. The room was very spacious and very comfortable with the king size bed, sitting area, small table and chairs, large flat screen, refrigerator, walk in shower and separate toilet. We enjoyed sitting on the beach every day.. They had nice loungers and very nice beach beds. We had read about how bad the beach was. However, the dark material along the shoreline was organic matter that washed into the ocean from one of the rivers on the property and settled on the bottom close to shore. I went in the water several times a day and about 10 feet out the bottom turned white again. It was not mucky walking through the organic matter. We watched workers taking the organic matter out and carrying it away in wheelbarrows where they would dry it and then use it as compost for their large nursery. There were basically two pools that meandered through the property. Both were huge. From the beginning of the pool closest to the resort to the end of the second pool by the beach, it probably extended almost two blocks. The first pool was the quiet pool with little nooks and crannies. The pool closest to the beach was the active pool. This pool also had three hot tubs on one side of the pool that had cool, warm and hot water. A full service bar was set up at the end of the pool closest to the beach that served the pool and beach. At the center of the two pools was a nice restaurant for lunch and an ala carte at night that also had a full bar. The food and wine selection couldn’t have been better. We went to an ala carte restaurant every night. Guests get lobster with their meal one night during the week and you pick the restaurant. We had our lobsters at the steak restaurant and it was a very nice meal. Some reports we read did not like the ala carte food. It sounded like they were complaining that you could not get spaghetti at the Italian restaurant or enchiladas at the Mexican restaurant. Neither one was on the menu but all you had to do was ask for a food item any place you were and they were more than glad to provide that food item even though it was not on the menu. Otherwise, the food at all the ala carte restaurants was very good with excellent presentations. The buffet we really enjoyed for breakfast and one or two lunches. The presentation was always impressive and the food was great. There may have been smaller portions on the buffet than some people liked but we didn’t need large quantities so we could try different things. There was a brick oven pizza place where we ate lunch a couple of times. The pizza place was next to the pool about halfway to the beach with umbrellas and tables in it’s own outside space. They had a number of pizzas on the menu but we ordered our pizzas with toppings we wanted and they were happy to do our special pizzas. Waiters were serving and taking orders at the pools and on the beach. They served a lot of pizza poolside for any and all that wanted one. Their entertainment every night was very good and enjoyable. One evening they had a Caribbean Night around the pool with a 7 piece band and two singers. They played while we ate from a buffet set up at the pool closest to the beach. The buffet was top notch with some great choices. The band was very good and made for a wonderful evening. We noticed a sign in the lobby one day advertising a world buffet and a show from Melissa in their show room. We decided to go and see what it was all about. Again, they did a fantastic job on the food in the buffet and the show that Melissa put on was one that you could see in Las Vegas. She is a very talented singer and dancer and had six dancers with her. It was a very fast pace show with lots of costume changes and some great dancing and singing. After the show we went to the lobby where they had a saxophone player playing. He was very good and it was a relaxing atmosphere in the evening breeze. We saw Melissa and her group come in the lobby and visited with her briefly and took pictures. She is delightful and a very talented lady. They had a fire show one night on the resort grounds that was very entertaining for the whole family. The service at Hacienda Tres Rios was exceptional. Every employee we encountered was pleasant, helpful and very service orientated. They were there to assist and make sure our time there was very enjoyable. One activity we really liked at the resort was the special activities in the afternoons. We attended three cooking classes put on by one of their chefs. We learned about the tastes of the Yucatan, three different moles and guacamole and salsas which we really enjoyed. Each chef would demonstrate how the foods are made, cooked, etc. and then we got to try them all. They also had a wine tasting one afternoon to try the eight different wines available at each of the restaurants provided from one Mexican winery. Tasting techniques and a little about each wine started the tasting. All of the wines were exceptional and very good and heads and shoulder above most resort house wines we have had. Another afternoon they had a tequila tasting. We tasted eleven different tequilas. Our tasting host told a little about each tequila and for each one we got a new glass. From the class we got an education in how different tequilas can be. Also while we were there we took their bicycle tour through the property where we saw several cenotes, their plant farm and the paths through the jungle. Another day we went on a tour of the plant farm operation and then jumped in one of the cenotes with mask and snorkel and drifted down one of the rivers into the ocean. It was a fun activity. All in all, the week at Hacienda Tres Rios was one of the most enjoyable weeks we have had in the Riviera Maya. The facility, room, food, service, drinks, etc. from start to finish were top notch. We would recommend this resort in a heart beat!!

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at a great resort”
Reviews.Author: Treeguy001
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 4 nights during a split stay. The grounds were beautiful, large, with trails to walk or run on. The Mayan show was great. The service was wonderful. The beach area was better than reported. The water was fairly clear and never saw debris on the beach. The rivers were cool, snorkeling down one of them. The tours were fantastic, always something to do. Rented a car from Royal, ended up with a nick next to the whell wellthat could have covered easily with touch up paint, but was charged $30 USD. I have 2 cons for the rooms; the TV is in the middle of the room, not directly in front of anything, it would have been betterif you could tilt it left or right depending if you want to watch it from the bed or the couch. The restaurants were good. The pizza oven is a wonderful plus, we ate there one lunch. The grill was great, especially as the steak house at night. Nice weather to eat outside. We tried the Japanese restuarant, but nothing on the menu cought our eye. The pools were wonderful, but no swim up bar. There was free internet in the rooms which was nice, but not always reliable.

Reviews.Title: “Most beautiful resort!”
Reviews.Author: RachelCC
Reviews.Content: We actually purchased the PRC (like a timeshare) with HTR. They are currently finishing up phase one, and I am proud to say, this complex is absolutely breathtaking! We've stayed at other 4 star hotels in the area, but this is by far the most beautiful and eco-friendly place thus far! Although a bit pricey, you do get what you pay for- at all levels. There are 9 restaurants, a theatre, sports bar, 9 cenotes to snorkel, scuba or swim in. There are bikes to coast along the 324 acres of land! There isn't a lot of people staying here- so no crowds. It's like staying on your very own multi-million dollar property with just you and your family!

Reviews.Title: “NEVER GO THERE. THEY ARE DISHONEST PEOPLE”
Reviews.Author: comptonsmith
Reviews.Content: I went to a time share presentation & was pressured into buying one, which I did NOT want to. According to the contract you have 5 days to cancell. I went back to them on the 5th day & said I was cancelling the contract. I had a paper written out with my name, contract number, and a letter explaining I was cancelling according to the contract on the 5th day. The contract also said I would get my money back (they took my credit card number & took almost $2,000.00 for the down payment) within 15 days. I did this all on 6/11/2010 & still have NEVER received my money back. I sent many emails and was ignored. I finally talked to a women in Texas who said they had agreed to everything & I would be getting my refund. That was in August. Now it is October 12th & I still have not received the refund of my money. I have again sent many emails and I get no returns from anyone. THIS COMPANY IS A RIP OFF!!!!! AND THEY ARE DISHONEST. I have the paper signed by someone very high up who agreed to the cancellation on 6/11, but still nothing. i suggest everyon BOYCOTT this resort!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort, just a little on the quiet side”
Reviews.Author: hfintexas
Reviews.Content: Hacienda Tres Rios is very beautiful, very clean, the staff is very friendly and accommodating and the beach and pools are lovely. We loved the "green juice" that we received upon check-in, and even though the hotel is all-inclusive the drinks are all top shelf and they will make you whatever you want. The food could be better. We experienced a rather average buffet with food that had been sitting around too long. Most of the restaurants at night have a dress code. (The exception is the poolside restaurant - which also happens to have the best food.) It would have been nice to experience the Mexican restaurant, but we were there to relax and spend time on the beach, etc - so the thought of getting all dressed up for dinner just didn't sound like fun. The resort could really use a more casual, "fun" evening restaurant - maybe with live music or something to liven up the resort's evening atmosphere. Most evenings found us in the town of Playa del Carmen (highly recommended!) at some local place or another. Due to the location of HTR, we ended up spending quite a bit on cab fare back and forth from the resort to Playa del Carmen because althought the resort is lovely - there is *nothing* going on at night. It's very quiet and was too quiet for us personally. That said, the location of HTR is special because of the spectaular access to the cenotes. We took the "Jaguar Tour" our first day here and I highly recommend that - you spend some time snorkeling in the cenote, which is the clearest water you will ever see - and then you sea kayak all the way down the cenote to where it meets the ocean and back. It's fantastic!

Reviews.Title: “Suckered into a time share...don't stay here!”
Reviews.Author: eggnbanana
Reviews.Content: The hotel is beautiful but I need to warn people not to stay here. The stress of it all is just not worth it. Find another hotel that is just as nice but doesn't come with a cost of sitting thru a sales pitch when you could be enjoying the beautiful beaches. They say it'll only take 90minutes but as I've read in other reviews, this is not the case. You will waste a full day if not more and feel quite pressured. Their sales techniques were distasteful and defintely left us feeling ill afterwards. They will make it sound like an amazing offer but if you read the the details and contracts in hard detail, you will find that it is not.

Reviews.Title: “Phenomenal Place, Incredible Experience!”
Reviews.Author: windaround
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a 6 day, 7 night trip to Tres Rios with a group of friends. We all traveled from different places, so by the time I arrived at 9:30 pm, everyone was already there (due to my late plane). The trip from Cancun was pretty short...not quite 30 minutes, and as we turned off of the highway, we traveled down a secluded road, with security to check us in, the low jungle/mangroves all around us. By the time I got out of the vehicle, I was so excited and anxious to see all of my friends. Erick showed me around and helped me to locate my friends having dinner. I was absolutely in awe of the beauty of the hotel. I had done a great deal of research prior to my trip, but you have to see this place in person in order to completely appreciate it. Our rooms were incredible-3 bathrooms, 2 bedrooms, dining/living room, balconies, and roof-top jacuzzi overlooking the sea. The beds were sooo comfortable. There was plenty of space for all of us to hang our clothes and put them away. Our fridges were stocked with Dos XX, sodas, and bottled water all week. The in-room dining staff was absolutely wonderful! Thank you all so much! Even when we knew the hotel was a bit busy, we always got our food and beverages in a timely manner. The housekeepers were always available with fresh, clean towels--which we were always in need of. We would leave in the mornings and come back to wonderfully clean rooms! (How I miss that! :)) Oh, and the showers and bathrooms were very nice. Loved all of the marble! Now the food....well, it was five-star all-around. Being in a group of 6 people, I was pretty much able to taste everything. We went to the Asian-fusion restaurant twice (because we loved it so much!) We had incredible service there, as well. We loved the sushi! We also went to the Mexican restaurant once for brunch during our timeshare presentation (I'll tell you about that shortly) and it was great! I wasn't sure about Mexican food for breakfast, but there were omelet stations and fresh fruit--but the best part was watching a woman make fresh tortillas and cooking them to order. We had mimosas (and more mimosas) and it was great. Dinner there was also fabulous! We did try the cricket empenadas! (At least most of us :)) Our waiter recommended the Mexican specialty plate which wasn't on the menu for me---Thank you! Again, dinner here was wonderful! We also went to the Italian restaurant. It was my birthday and we had special reservations. The food was fantastic. But the best part was at the end of the meal. Everyone sang to me as an adorable and BIG cake was brought to our table. And that cake was HEAVENLY! Our waiter recommended the Mayan coffee for me--and what a great show! Thanks for a great birthday! :) Okay, so those were the fine-dining restaurants. Now my group and I...we love to eat! We spent a couple of long days at the pool and received spectacular service. It is hard to remember everyone's names, as they were all so wonderful! We loved the pizza place with all of their specialties and the grill---Loved the grilled shrimp. The customer service was top-notch. I was able to order a special salad and they even created large platters for us to munch on. Just watch out for the birds!! Drinks were always plentiful and service was even available to us out on the beach beds! Our last day was a Saturday and we had a great time at the pool--thank you, Sergio--wish you all the best! And thanks to all of the cooks who brought out the samples of the amazing food not available on the menu--coconut shrimp, sauteed crab tostadas.... The buffet was decent. I'm not much of a buffet fan, but it was nice to have a quick choice for breakfast. One morning we were in a rush and the hostesses let us go in and get breakfast to-go! They were so sweet! We managed to get to the cafe on our last night. What incredible desserts and pastries! I am a coffee drinker so having an espresso machine there was great! The two men working there were wonderful and even went to get me a Grand Marnier and recommended other liquors to try with my espresso. This was the night I met Chef Oscar. He was so very nice to us and I had to thank him for all of the wonderful food! Just wish we had had the chef's dinner :( I think I've reviewed all of the restaurants--and I hope I've been able to relate what a wonderful time we had EATING! Of course though, even though the food was fantastic--it was the service that made it so special!! I said I'd report on the time-share presentation. Well, I was pretty apprehensive about all of it, to be honest. I'd been looking forward to this trip for 6 months, so I'd read all of the reviews here on TripAdvisor. Some of them were pretty awful, especially in regards to the time share schpeel. It was my birthday, so my friend and I woke up ready to either cancel or reschedule our 9:30 appointment. But we all decided to tough it out. In all actuality, the demographics of our group may have been a deciding factor in the treatment from the presenters....but it really wasn't all that terrible. It did last longer than initially stated, but we knew we were getting free transportation to Playa del Carmen--and we got to eat. Some of the information was interesting and our salesman did his best (I told you it was my birthday, right? He ordered and we drank 2 bottles of champagne!) and yes, a couple of other sales managers came over to our table and tried different tactics...great deals waved in front of us...but all in all--i guess it could of been a lot worse according to the other reviewers. Four of my friends were able to get tickets to Xel-Ha/tour of Tulum out of it, as well. (Two were free--two highly discounted--and if the other two of us had wanted to go...well, it would of been a great deal more expensive--even after half-off). But that was fine--part of being a large group means we could do different things--I had already saw Tulum, and Akumal has the most AMAZING snorkeling!!! The beach was nice. We all loved the natural beauty of it and the entire resort. We went kayaking and saw of the damage from the hurricane 5 years ago so we understood why the beach wasn't like the beach at Playa, Tulum, or even Akumal. And we were okay with it. The first night I jumped in and a couple days later I explored the shallow waters of what looks like a lagoon with clear blue waters. My friends had a great time jumping off of the dock--I had fun seeing all of the tropical fish, giant jellyfish, and barracudas! :) Onto nightlife...I tried to make it to some of the shows....but ended up catching the very end of the Mayan fire show; everyone else said it was great. We listened and danced to Caribbean music in the sports bar, and some of us joined in on casino night and the auction. Mostly though, we sat outside of the sports bar and had drinks in the evenings when we were not in Playa. I knew beforehand that Tres Rios would be very luxurious and romantic. That was fine for all of us, and as one of the singles in our group, I enjoyed the peace and quiet. It was so relaxing and rejuvenating. (Thanks, Daniel, for the wonderful massage!) A couple of nights, though, we wanted to go out and see what the nights were like in Playa. We found out that the resort has an entertainment team. They will take you into town and to Coco Bongo, if you so wish. We decided against that and went out on our own. It probably equaled to be of the same expense, but we still had a great time! If you choose to go out you have to call a taxi, which is kind of expensive, but it is the safest way to travel at night. During the day, the collectivo is the way to go! Hacienda Tres Rios is a phenomenal resort! The Riviera Maya is paradise and Tres Rios is one of its hidden gems! I was sad to leave...but of course it is good to be home! Back to work I go! Thank you, everyone who took the time to make sure we had an incredible vacation! I had an amazing experience in the Riviera Maya...one I will never forget!

Reviews.Title: “amazing”
Reviews.Author: bradheitsman
Reviews.Content: this resort is the best place i have stayed at.The employes are a class act very thankful for sol,motego and corina from entertainment,migel and paulo,these people made my vacation even more pleasent.If you ever get the chance to stay at this resort you would never regret it.My girlfriend and i with a friend came in sept. when its not the busiest time of year and got the best service possible!!.the food is awesome plenty to choose from,and really enjoyed the 24 hour room service.This resort is not in town but they have made it so you dont even need to leave.There is so much to do at this resort that if you stay for a week it seem not to be enough!!!I highly recommened this resort to anyone wanting a romantic setting to the whole family.If you get a chance to stay here trust me take it!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent if you are a resort only person”
Reviews.Author: ReRog100
Reviews.Content: Very cool place if you are a "Green" person the things they have done since the hurricane in 2007 is great. They care for the forna and funa and supply other resorts from there exoctic greenhouse. Now for the hotel, very beautiful and spacious. Pool area is huge no need to save chairs unless you want the same chair everyday. Pool side service is great, many wait staff in area. Cool part is as with some pool areas food is allowed and the grill puts out some great food and also personal pizzas that are brick oven cooked. Evening dining is also very good. You need some reservations but easy to get. Some activities is a fresh water river that runs thru the resort and a cenote. If you just want to relax and eat, drink, and watch some good evening shows then this is your resort, if you are for the off resort nightlife such as Senor Frogs and such then stay in Cancun.

Reviews.Title: “You need to be there! Relax-Relax-Relax”
Reviews.Author: ez_going-south
Reviews.Content: This place is an exceptionally great resort with many ammenities available to you and a staff who is ready and eager to assist with your needs. You are greeted with a warm "hacienda style greeting" as you enter into the large lobby. Check in has always been a smooth transition. You are soon directed to and introduced to your concierge who takes the time to explain all of your options availabe to you. Although they may be courtious, there's still a bit of work that needs to be refined in that area and I'm sure over time they will. (we call em "growing pains) Upon arriving to your room you can't denie many of the breath talking views of the grounds and Carribiean Sea. The rooms are clean and airy and the beds are comfortable to say the least. With lots of daily activities throughout. We opt out on some to take in the warm sun and do what we don't often get a chance to do at home. "...and that is to relax by the pool." But of course, who can resist the mountain bike tour in the a.m.? The girls were a blast to have as tour guides. They were knowledgable of their surroundings and concerned for your well being. Thank you Daniella! Other ventures were also taken advantage of like Kayaking up the mouth of the river, and an awesome tour on their Hobie-cats to visit an awesome reef filled with muli-colored fish that you sure won't see back home! If your more of the advensurous type and would like to explore more of the Yucatan Penninsula, well there's plenty to do. You also have Playa de Carmen nearby, where you can shop their "5th Avenue" shops for just about anything. Not to mention, you can hop onto a ferry and head over to the popular Island of Cozumal and be there within minutes. This time around, we decided to just stay put and enjoy all that the resort had to offer. Overall the service was exceptional and the food was great as expected for the amount paid. With many options available to you, we cannot overlook our fabulous lunches prepared by the great group (or team) from the Mexican Grill alongside the pools. Don't get me wrong, you gotta try the hand made-oven baked pizzas and calzones! They're to die for. You just don't want the day to end. The service is great for the most part and as I had mentioned, the food is fabulous. There is one guy who stands out well beyond the rest and is evitable to those who have gone to HTR. And that is Samuel (or Sammy for us Gringos) This guy is the backbone of what goes on around you and I am very greatful for him and his willingness to go out of his way to see that you are well taken care of. He takes on many rolls and can muli-task to see that things are going well. HTR has a gem with this this guy and if they were smart, they would give him a raise $$ and get a few more like him around the facility. (truly a great investment!) Did you say beaches? Well, sad to say, "if your looking for a great white sandy beach at this place, look elsewhere" cause this one is far from that. Hopefully there is much more progress done when we return next year. The water is warm but it's about as red as they come, thanks to the ever growing mangrove all around. The beach are is rather small considering but it has a long way to go to be up to par. The big beds are a nice comodity and something different and thats good. But the water..."Thumbs down for that" You'll have to drive down to Playa de Carmen for better than that and if you do, stop by the Sunset Fishermen for a cool drink. Keep in mind, this is a rather new facility and staff and there's going to be new issues arising here and there. (hopefully not buit you can't get away from that) Take for instance, while we were there the first time in '09, all the facility power went out tempararly in the evening. No fun! ...This time the water main had gone out on two separate days. Fortunately the refrigeraters are well stocked with bottled water but don't try to take a shower or flush the toilets! ! ! So what do you do? Dwell on the negative or enjoy your vacation? ...Exactly! Overall, we had a great experience to say the least. This place is fabulous but don't tell everyone. It's our secret! Kudos to everyone on-board! I can't wait to get back in '11. Hope to see you there! Gracias Tres Rios!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, interesting, but...not a 5 star Resort.”
Reviews.Author: ArkSw
Reviews.Content: We booked our trip with RCI exchange after reading reviews and seeing photos that were very beautiful. We arrived at approximately 3 pm, very tired and hungry from a day of travel, anxious to get to our suite which advertised 3 pm check in. We were met by our concierge, a nice young lady and offered a nice juice drink,. 2 hours later we were still trapped by the lady who was basically trying to sign us up for a time share sales presentation, which we repeatedly told her we had no interest in. Our reservation was not based on the requirement that we attend, and we did pay in addition to the exchange a considerable amount for the all inclusive. After getting a bit cranky with her we were "released" and allowed to go to our suite. It was insinuated that we would not be able to participate in the resort activities unless we attended the sales tour. This was not a positive start to our vacation. Our suite: Beautiful, marble everywhere, two bathrooms, wonderful balcony with a view of the pool area and the ocean. Crows nest up a circular staircase where you can sun bathe or look at the moon reflecting on the ocean. Best nights sleep ever in a resort, very comfortable. Service: Fantastic! Great attitudes, and willing to go out of their way to satisfy your needs. We became especially fond of Ivan a server at the Hacienda Grill, Food: Average to excellent depending on what you like and what was available. Anything prepared with fresh lime was terrific, wonderful sauces and fresh ingredients.The Tuna and Sea Bass Crevice was excellent, peach crepes, fried shrimp platter we got pool side was awesome, but not on the menu. The buffet was a disappointment , Nice fruit bar but I was disappointed in the lack of variety, and little local produce. Lots of cantaloupe, honey dew, watermelon, etc. average fare. They do have an omelet bar that is good. Dinner or lunch at the buffet was average food, like you might find at a U.S. cafeteria. The Mexican restaurant was good, interesting menu, and do try the Crickets. Meat is not of the quality we are used to in the U.S., but flavorful. Usually over cooked and a bit dry even when requesting medium rate. . Fish was wonderful, but not on the menu. Menus are very lacking, the best food available is not on a menu, its like hide and seek, but takes a few days to learn the ropes/ Desserts were a big disappointment. Very pretty but lacked flavor and often an odd consistency in cakes. The pastry shop has good coffee, but no pastry to speak of. Some little confections but again that spongy texture. No muffins, or croissants.And it does not open until 3 pm. Location: Not a good beach to swim off of, they have a lot of debris from the mangroves, they water is very dark brown. They work endlessly to keep the beach area clean, and have wonderful beds to nap on. A big plus is access to the rivers flowing from the cenotes. You can kayak up the rivers to a cenote, or walk over a bridge to a lovey platform with hammocks and enjoy the ocean breeze. Although they are a lovely park they have claimed less than 20 percent of the actual property, so your excursions are short and limited. The Jaguar Tour is great and a wonderful introduction to the area. However there are many resorts in the area that offer far more interaction with nature than Tres Rios can at this stage. Over all? They want to be a 5 star and in some ways they are. Then fall very short of it on food, providing information to guests, entertainment, and some conveniences.
