Another example of catering to the "VIP's" was that there was a wedding on Saturday night while we were there. While this is no big deal to us, they shut down the sports bar (for a large portion of the evening) and the outside restaurant to the rest of the guests. Without the sports bar open, there is almost nothing to do at night, not even anywhere to get a drink after 10:30 pm when the bar in the Mexican restaurant closes. We thought they could have made other accommodations for the guests that were not part of the wedding. Service by the pool was very spotty. Sometimes they would ask if you wanted a drink, most times they would just walk right by and purposely avoid eye contact with you as to avoid having to take your order. One time our lunch order was completely forgotten, and the waiter told us one hour later that he simply forgot. The pools are kept very nice and don't seem to get much use. It was relatively easy to get a chair...some people play the "towel game" but not many. The beach is as everyone describes - seaweed/mangrove roots on the sand and dirty brown water. Workers were out there every day all day long cleaning it up (seems like a losing battle). But we knew this ahead of time from reading reviews here, so it wasn't a big deal. The rivers were more interesting to us, since they are different from most other resorts. While they have various guided tours (kayaking, snorkeling), they don't really advertise the fact that you can do these on your own at any time you want. We constantly had to prompt our guide for more information, as she always gave out as little as possible. For example, we took a group bike tour, and we were with a group much slower than us. The guide noticed that we were bored and said that we could take the bikes on our own some other time. However, I had to prompt for more information such as "where do you get the bikes?" and "when can you get them?". The exact same thing happened when kayaking as well. We felt as though they didn't advertise their nature activities to the maximum extent considering that it really sets them apart. The sports bar was the only place to go after 10:00pm, and even then on some nights it was completely dead. There just isn't much going on at this place. A few nights they did have shows (fire show, Mayan show, Canadian Idol winner played for us), but none of these were very heavily attended. The fire show was of very good quality though. Two of the activities directors (Tony and Andy) made good efforts to get people involved (volleyball during the day, dancing in the bar at night). In fact, they seemed like the two happiest people at the resort. A visit to a nightclub in PDC was also set up and attended by them one night. It's just that most people don't take part in these things. Regarding the head chef, Oscar, he is as good as everyone else says. We saw him every day around all parts of the resort. When he was around, the service improved. It was obvious that all of the other workers put much more effort in when he was watching. The food was good in all of the restaurants; the buffet was just average. Overall, we picked this place because of prior good reviews on Trip Advisor, but based on current reviews and our own experience, this place seems to be going downhill fast. Had we not visited other resorts in the past, we might have had a better rating of HTR, but knowing what else is out there for the price, this place is just average.

Reviews.Title: “I'll try to be accurate, honest, and objective.”
Reviews.Author: comicmasters
Reviews.Content: I like using tripadvisor to get as much info as possible about a resort to choose the best vacation for my family. So if you're doing the same, here goes. 1. Even though this is an All Inclusive club, expect to tip. You get some pretty good pressure, it's never said, but boy are they working for it, sometimes overtly. 2. The workers are all very friendly. 3. No map of the grounds so you're going to have to struggle slightly to figure the place out. I'll tell you that for 326 acres, it's a pretty small place. 4. 24 hour room service was pretty good and punctual. 5. The Food. Of all the meals Kytori was the best. After that it wasnt anything to write home about. 2 inside restaurants not including the buffet. 1 poolside restaurant. And 1 brick oven for pizza restaurant. 6. And if you like lobster you have to inform the resort 24 hours in advance of when you want it. I was disappointed of this because I told my son he could have it every day if he wanted. II'm letting you know that because I was never told that. If you want lobster for dinner, order it now. 7. I have 3 kids that are a little older 11,12, and 15. They kind of fall through the cracks at a resort such as this. They have a kids club, but it's for little kids 6 & under. Now we can entertain ourselves and we did, but when you consider the options provided by a Palace Resort, it was disappointing. We took the cenote eco-tour which we recommend, and we took the bike tour which we enjoyed(bikes need some work though). They had a Mayan show which the kids enjoyed. Gambling night with fake money was fun. Rented a car to get away from the resort and went to Tulum and Tulum beach which was awesome. Went to xcaret which was a good time. 8. If you don't need a nice beach, then you might be ok. The courtyard is beautiful. You can be lazy at the pool all day long and enjoy youself just fine, especially if you can entertain yourself. 9. If you need a beach that is picturesque and is what comes to mind when you think of the Mayan Riveria, you will not like it here. We stayed 4 days, and not one person went in that water. And I like to swim at the beach as do my 3 kids. 10. I booked this trip through luxury link which had built into it several very nice additions such as a private moonlight dinner, massages, special breakfast in room, and jacuzzi rose petal room preparation upon arrival. - I had to inform the resort of all of these while they were trying to get me to go to the private residence seminar upon arrival which is their timeshare. I was told all would be taken care of. The last thing you want to get hit with is the timeshare spiel before you have a chance to eat or get your room. However, to be fair, that is commonplace of not only this resort but many in Mexico. - We did not get a jacuzzi rose petal room preparation upon arrival. - Massages were great, spa facility private and seemed on par with a nice resort. - Private moonlight dinner was awesome (thank you Hector), this saved the trip for me as it was my 20th wedding anniversary. - However, as soon as something nice would happen....they forgot to give us our special in room breakfast when we asked for it. Picture yourself waiting in your room for a breakfast that isnt coming when there are restaurants right below you. I'll tell you, you feel stupid. After telling our personal Concierge of the oversight she passed me off to the girl who set it up. This girl as nice as she was said she could set up another breakfast or send a special gift to the room. I said out of the two choices, send something to the room then. It never came. We shielded our kids from the shortcummings of the resort and all in all they had a fantastic time as did my wife and I. But, when you take a vacation such as this you like to be treated like royalty. The missteps made by this resort made me look bad in front of my family on more than one occasion. And that is unacceptable for a resort that you are essentially spending a $1,000 a day on(after airfare). I can in good conscience tell you that if you are looking for the royal treatment, you and your family will be better served by investigating other options. All the best!

Reviews.Title: “Nice Resort....No activities”
Reviews.Author: Addiene
Reviews.Content: I just got back from a week long stay at Tres Rios...This is a very beautiful resort and the food was good but I would not recommend this place to anyone..Lets start with check-in..it was a nightmare we were taken to the sports bar where a lady was suppose to tell us about the resort she did a terrible job and after an hour we were able to go to our room which was wrong but we got that staightened out quickley..The staff that checked us in really had no idea what they were doing..We did not attend the time share thing so we could not take advantage of the free taxi to Playa..The pool area was a big maze and there was only one bathroom outside and it seemed like everytime we went to use it someone was in there cleaning it. The resort was like a ghost town at night very little to do and the shows were over by 9:30.The sports bar was more like a meeting room. There were no activities or music during the day around the pool..very boring. It was also a little strict..We got yelled at for bringing our lunch into the sports bar told u could not eat in there but the had a buffet set up in there on saturday...The shows were ok..would not recommend going to see Millissa..They really need to use the theater for more activities..The food was really good but the buffets were kinda boring..The other restuarant required men to wear long pants and they would not let u in if you had shorts on..I found this silly b/c the restuarant was right with the buffett.. The staff was really nice although you had to wait awhile for things around the pool..Our room was always clean and room service was quick..all and all it was a nice trip.

Reviews.Title: “Dont get ripped off.”
Reviews.Author: jonnyda
Reviews.Content: We stayed here with friends that own a timeshare . We did not opt for the all inclusive package .Three out of 4 of us are in the hospitality and convention business, one is a chef. We have worked in the NY area, and know food cost and quality, so we quickly figured out that what they were charging for AI is outrageous.We had stayed previously in PDC at hotels where the food was much better and reasonably priced. Members of our party were also treated rudely by staff on on more than one occasion. Be careful and keep your receipts as there were charges we were not told about, and nothing is in writing. Check your cc receipts on your return.If we did business like this in the US, the BBB and the AGs offices would be notified. Would not recommend this resort -getting nickel and dimed to death feels like work -BTW we said NO to the time share presentation .Overall, felt there was deception, especially from front desk staff and MGMT. Most of the services staff very friendly-and should note here-we tipped well when we asked for anything even though we did not use the dining /liquor services and sampled the food at a welcome party for time share owners. If your wrist band comes off - they will charge you $100 US. No one told us this up front and it is not posted anywhere in writing. There are better beaches, better dining at so many resorts in PDC to recommend this resort to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “What is your name and where you came from?”
Reviews.Author: Lick-A-Pringle
Reviews.Content: We visited H3R for a week in March on an all-inclusive plan. I will begin by giving this property 8 stars out of a possible10. The H3R could become a 10 with some simple process improvements of which I’ll describe below: Dining There are several dining options throughout the property. The Hacienda Grill (9 out of 10) is a full service, outdoor restaurant by the pool. The service was top notch and the menu had a good selection so we weren’t bored with the offerings. If you request lobster one day prior to dining in this facility for an evening meal, it will be grilled to perfection the next night. I had the grouper and a chicken kebob on two other occasions, both of which were excellent. In the evening, Kenny G.’s Latino cousin provides saxophone entertainment to prerecorded Rat Pack tracks with a sprinkle of Stevie Wonder and Bette Midler. The servers here are on top of their game and provide a pleasant experience. At Il Forno Pizzeria (8 out of 10) you can get a quick, brick-oven pizza in about 5 minutes or less. At this outdoor restaurant near the pool, there are a few options for pizza and calzones available, but they can make you just about any off-menu pizza/calzone you’d like. Be wary of the Italian sausage pizza. It’s basically a cheese pizza with hot dogs. Ack! They also serve beer which is great while you wait out that painful 5 minutes for your pie. I only ate at El Alebrije (4 out of 10) for lunch one day because we were tired of the Casa Las Islas buffet. The selection is limited and somewhat bland. It’s convenient because there is a full bar in the facility (oh, and don’t by shy to ask for a tequila sampling) and the “brown” margaritas are tasty. The lunch buffet had fish, steak and chicken spirals with some corn and rice. The cilantro soup was good, but we stayed away from the salad bar. It included hot dog salad. Weird. Don’t try to eat here for breakfast because it if for timeshare converts only. Lunch starts around 12:30 p.m. I rated it low because of the poor selection on the buffet and the hot dog salad. Casa Las Islas (6 out of 10) is a standard buffet near the main lobby. After you eat here a couple of times you’ll be tired of the limited selection. Breakfast always includes an omelet bar, a yogurt station, a bread/pastries area, some cereal and then a grouping of random hot foods, which include: bacon, link sausage (not hot dogs), wheat pancakes with 4 kinds of syrup, waffles, chicken, turkey, fish, and refried beans. There are also fresh fruits, cheeses and oatmeal. The service was prompt, but be prepared to wait for a seat if you show up late or have a large party if the resort is full. Honestly, the food was good, just reparative. There is a bar in the restaurant so you can get your Bloody Mary, mimosa, beer or whatever you can stomach at 8 a.m. Lunch is a little better. The staples there seem to be chicken nuggets and French fries along with a small pasta bar replacing the omelet station. Same goes for dinner. As always, the service is outstanding. I would rate this higher, but my stomach gets a little queasy just thinking about eating there again. If you’ve ever done the cabbage soup diet in your life, it’s like how the soup makes you feel on the 5th day. I am not sure why I thought I’d enjoy Asian food in Playa del Carmen, and Kotori (4 out of 10) reinforced my mindset. It’s only open for dinner on certain days of the week and is also just off the lobby. I had various appetizers including sushi and spring rolls. The spring rolls were OK. But my entrée which was beef and noodles looked disgusting and tasted disgusting. My servers, Gustavo (he’s amazing!) and Geronimo (he’s pretty good!), kept the food and drinks coming. Since the beef and noodles was inedible, he brought me some tempura seafood which turned out to be shrimp, salmon and cod deep fried in Bisquik and honey. Not good either. I say skip it all together, but if you do, you’ll miss out on Kenny G.’s other Latino cousin providing inspirational flute entertainment. On the days that the restaurant isn’t disguised as Kotori, it becomes Porto Bello (9 out of 10). I suppose Mexicans can do Italian properly. I had waaaaaaaaaaaaay too much to drink during the day and opted for Grandma’s Pasta which was just spaghetti and marinara. There were several appetizers to choose from including a goat cheese salad and raw tuna. Gustavo and Geronimo were taking care of us again, so it made it even better. Some others in my party had the veal and/or beef medallions and just loved them. This on is worth a visit, and if you’re lucky, Kenny G.’s Latino cousin-once-removed will entertain you with his Pavarotti-like vocal stylings. He is a little pitchy (dawg!) and likes to hang on to some of his notes for about 30-seconds of sustained vibrato. Finally there is the Victory Sports Bar (6 out of 10) which shouldn’t really be called a sports bar at all. That’s unless you think pool, bingo and Jenga qualify as sports in your book. It is, if anything, a good bar which has prompt service. I highly recommend Carlos in this facility. He rocks! There are about five 32” TVs mounted on the walls and none of them carried the NCAA tournament which started this week. Turn out the only have cable service (no satellite) so we were stuck watching Iron Man, Hispanic music videos and futbol. This room also serves as the registration area on check in days (horrible process, by the way) and the concert facility for local favorite, Melissa. Only 12 people showed up for her performance on Monday night, so either she sucks or H3R doesn’t advertise well. This is a fine place to hang out when it’s raining or if you get the itch to play Jenga. If you choose to use Room Service (8 out of 10), you really can’t go wrong. They’re open 24 hours a day and will make whatever you want. If you use the ICE computer in your room or call it in, give yourself a 15-30 minute buffer. We used it two or three times and each time the delivery came later than when we asked for it. It’s also nice to be able to eat in your room. Strangely, they’ve never heard of peanut butter so you’re not getting any of that with your toast, buddy boy! And don’t forget to tip a couple of bucks for the effort. Recreation We used a kayak from the cenotes end, up the river to the beginning and back. It was about a half mile each way. You can also rent a Hobie cat and do some quick sailing in the ocean. Whoever was working the recreation table on the beach was on a prolonged break or something so we just took one. It was good times and the water was so clear. You’ll need bio-degradable sunscreen and mosquito repellant to partake. And even when the staff tells you there aren’t any mosquitoes (it’s too cold, there aren’t any here, wrong season for mosquitoes, etc.), believe me, there are! And they love to bit Americans and Canadians. Drink as much as you can beforehand so at least the critters will die a little happier before you slap them into a bloody speckle. Do the snorkel tour, as well. It’s a self-paced swim with the cenote current. Lots of fish to be discovered and branches to smack you when you’re not paying attention. Oh, and the water was co-oh-old! Chilly willy, but worth it. The botanical tour isn’t very interesting (but I was drunk and wanted to swim) and doesn’t take too long prior to the swim. If you can find a willing and competent member of the concierge staff (I couldn’t) they will set you up for the excursion. The concierge is basically worthless. Anyone in the lobby or sits behind a desk are worthless. They tell you to go somewhere else for information that they should have readily available. A person we traveled with got so fed up with them that he put a dead fish in their trashcan because they couldn’t figure out a way to have one of the chef’s cook it for him for dinner after a deep sea fishing excursion. They don’t know anything about area excursions or tours in Playa del Carmen or in Cancun. They blow. Oh, and the bell staff dress like pirates so it was somewhat fun for me to yell "Arrrrrrrrggggggggghhhh!" everytime I saw one. We spent most of the time at the family pool even though we didn’t bring kids. It’s closer to the satellite bar, the beach, hot tubs and these amazing wicker couches to lay out on. The beach is small but nice. The crew is cleaning out a lot of the nasty seaweed so it’s a prettier beach. You can walk out on the pier and can see Cozumel on the horizon. You can also walk down the beach to the neighboring resorts. They’re massive, packed full of people and nowhere near as nice as the H3R. Accommodations and Service The rooms are some of the best I’ve ever stayed in while in Mexico. From bed comfort to water pressure, you will not be disappointed. Housekeeping was excellent with cleaning and turndown service. The TV has HBO and (my favorite) the American Network which was basically CBS/Viacom programming. ABC also has a channel. There is a DVD player in the room and we brought a few episodes of Dexter and a Netflix movie to watch. Worked like a charm. There are multiple inputs on the flat screen TV so you can hook whatever you’d like up the TV. The ICE computer is a little bit fickle. It’s touch screen and I had to unplug it a few times so it would reboot to get it to work. Overall, I like the technology integration. Too bad they don’t have technology for a lot of other systems. The armband system for all-inclusive plans is somewhat painful. Be prepared to give everyone on the staff you deal with your room number. Check-in was disorganized. Upon arrival we went to the Victory Bar and sat around. There was no one available to explain the process, they just brought drinks and some light appetizers. After several drinks, most people didn’t care about the disorganization. Inebriation was an effective Band-Aid, but why not fix the process so the guest’s sense of arrival is phenomenal? It didn’t ruin the trip. I would have to say that the service in every area except for the front desk and concierge is amazing. There is an executive chef named Oscar who you’d think was a local celebrity who is omnipresent. He seemed to be extremely effective at making things happen. I never met the owner or GM of the property, but employees hopped when Oscar gave an order. I wound up going to him whenever I needed something because he had the ability (and motivation) to make things happen while others either made excuses or said “no”. This resort could use a few more Oscars in the lobby! Spa Be careful! I was at the H3R with 12 other people and more than half were charged something different than they were quoted from the spa staff. Curiously, when confronted about the discrepancy, the spa employee was nowhere to be found. Also, make sure they don’t accept your reservation on a Post It note. If they do, then that’s the same as not having a reservation. The staff is highly unapologetic and indifferent to your dilemma. While relaxing, the spa services are overpriced so be sure to haggle and get the best deal available. The steam room and exercise equipment were nice, however, my wife and I couldn't sit in the steam room for long because we kept getting hit with little scalding meteorites from the ceiling. Other I have heard a lot of people mention that the timeshare folks are pushy and aggressive. Although I wasn’t interested, not one timeshare employee approached me the whole week I was there. I kind of felt like the last kid picked on a baseball team except that I didn’t get picked and didn’t want to get picked. The weather was great, the bar service was great (don’t forget to tip a little for even faster service!) and I didn’t think about work once. The transportation to and from H3R is ridiculously expensive, so I don’t have any good ideas for you there. We had a group of 13 so we split two vans at $10 a person. To travel one way as a couple, it’s $80. There must be a better way. Some of the nightly shows were entertaining (Mayan dance, Caribbean party, Fire show) and it was nice to see some organization to it. The Latin American Idol and Canadian Idol were there for a performance one night. Not very many people showed up and it wasn’t very impressive. Again, like Melissa, it sucked or wasn’t advertised well. Nevertheless, I am home now and sifting through nine inches of snow wishing I was back on the Mayan Rivera working on my sunburn. H3R is a great place and I am very critical, so I hope you enjoy your trip as much as I did. Peace out.

Reviews.Title: “Lacking in amenities, very boring, no activites, disgusting beach area”
Reviews.Author: youngSTL
Reviews.Content: Just returned from 6 nights at this resort. We quickly figured out that this place is VERY QUITE, when we arrived and there were less than 25 people in the lobby, INCLUDING STAFF! Instead of taking you to your room after check in, a "salesperson" is assigned to you to try to get you to set up a tour of the property. After a day of delayed travel, our yawns finally convinced her to let us get to our rooms. The property is nice, however everything is a walk. 1 bathroom in the pool area, only 2 drink areas, only 2 choices for food outside, a grill and a woodfire pizza area (this was one of the better choices). The buffet breakfast was decent. Dinner choices were the buffet (looked limited in choices did not eat here), the steakhouse/asian/italian combo restaraunt (not bad) and the Mexican restaraunt ( would highly reccommend this one). HOWEVER, if you are an active family, this resort IS NOT FOR YOU! Only outdoor activity offered was volleyball at 11am and 3pm. Had a soccer field, BUT NO BALLS!! If your idea vacation is to lay around and do nothing, I STILL WOULD NOT RECCOMMEND this place!! Service is spotty at best. If they are on the same level as the "Ritz Carlton" as the salesperson told us, they obviously have never been to the Ritz, or think we are stupid!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely place, lousy attitudes”
Reviews.Author: wspivak
Reviews.Content: We just came back from TresRios. It truly is a beautiful place, a little maze like, but well appointed, clean with a service staff (waiters, barmen, service people) that were just delightful. BUT, as many people have said, they attack you upon registering to buy this, buy that, get this, get that, take their sales tour, etc. My answer is NO. I also said no to an outrageous all-inclusive price. Well, we became 2nd class citizens... their food prices make the fine restaurants in New York City that I frequent look like the corner diners in 1950. They should be ashamed of themselves. Another issue is the quality of the staff in the lobby (we're talking about anyone behind a desk). Poor doesn't quite fit. NO one either knew any answers or gave us wrong answers or misleading answers or contradictory answers. As good at the outside people were are as bad as the inside people are. I would not recommend this hotel, nor would I come pack...

Reviews.Title: “Couldn't Wait to Leave”
Reviews.Author: RamblinMan55
Reviews.Content: First a little background on this trip. We were given a week at a timeshare as a gift from a friend. We added a few extra days and tried out the cabana on the beach approach in Tulum (Hotel Nueva Vida). We LOVED the beach cabana. By comparison going from cabana to the Tres Rios was like checking into a hospital. Don't get me wrong the place is clean and the grounds are beautiful well kept and certainly very new. However, it felt sterile and very much like an institution, not my idea of a vacation resort. Because we were a guest of a timeshare owner we were "marked." As soon as we arrived we were "captives." Herded into a room and forced to wait and go thru three different people who overloaded us with information and wanted decisions. The main one, of course, being when wanted to schedule our personal tour and timeshare pitch! We wanted none of that. Made that clear. But they don't want to hear that of course. The biggest "gottcha" is that you can stay at this place without the all inclusive plan, which is what we booked. We had a car and planned to spend a bit of time in Playa and figured there was no way would would consume $150 a day per person in food--which is what it would cost to upgrade to the AI plan. We did think we would buy a few meals on site... ah... but here is the "gottcha" --the buffet prices: breakfast $30, lunch $40, dinner $50 per person. You gotta be kidding! Oh you could order during the day at the snack bars for like $15 for a hamburger, one of the cheapest things on the menu. (The eyes of the person checking us in actually registered disappointment when we informed her we had a rental car... without that you really would not have much choice!) One of the reasons we like to vacation in this area is because of the beautiful beaches and oceans... forget that at Tres Rios. This is a resort built on what is basically a swamp. Yes it is a pretty area, and yes there are lovely things to see and do here. But you are in the Caribbean, if I want swamp I will vacation in the Everglades! The ocean is not really swimmable, has lots of brown stuff floating in it. Since rivers converge here, there is a distinctive odor that I associate with stagnate water. Yuck The rooms were nice enough, free wireless, nice amenities. After the cabana on the beach we traded for a swamp view room at the Tres Rios. :( The saving grace was that they have some sister resorts where you have privileges--one of those is The Sunset Fisherman in Playa Del Carmen. We went there as soon as we could escape from the check-in hell. We loved the Sunset and immediately began to investigate the possibility of moving to this resort. We checked into the Tres Rios on Saturday and were told we could not be moved until Monday, and then only if there was space available. So we spent the days at the Sunset, and only slept at the Tres Rios. Monday we were told we could switch... but only if we did the Timeshare presentation... so we sighed heavily and endured the two hour ordeal. We moved to the Sunset and enjoyed that property immensely. Bottom line, if you offered me a free vacation at Tres Rios I would run the other direction as fast as I could...

Reviews.Title: “A vacation to remember...service from morning to night!”
Reviews.Author: Saltydogcafe
Reviews.Content: The staff, right from our arrival until our departure, were always so pleasant and friendly. We loved the pool or beach side service for lunch, a very nice treat if you did not want to leave the sunshine. Oscar's "chef''s table" is an experience in itself, we enjoyed a quiet celebration and had one on one service by Oscar and his assistant. We read many bad reviews about the timeshare aspect of this place. We declined the timeshare sales presentation and were not pressured to take it. Rooms are state of the art with hi-def televisions and touch screen computers etc. As this is a new resort they are making upgrades-one suggestion would be to post the days activities in the lobby or on the pool deck. Food choices were numerous and included everything from pizza and burgers to lobster and filet mignon. A few guests mentioned that they felt the food should have been "spicier" because it was Mexico. We found all you had to do was ask and they would make the food hot enough to bring tears to your eyes! Overall this is a beautiful resort and would recommend it if you are looking for a place to relax and have quiet evenings. Great Value but like anything other commodity it pays to shop. We paid far less than most other people we spoke with.

Reviews.Title: “Don't plan on going back or recommending”
Reviews.Author: lovetotravek
Reviews.Content: This resort has a great ecological theme is beautifully landscaped, comfortable rooms, etc. It is "optional" all-inclusive (about $120 pp per day). It is newer(only officially opened since December 09) with a lot of things to work on. Consistent service by the pool for one. Communication about nightly entertainment pretty much non-existent unless a staff member performing happened to walk by on his/her way to performance. Actually, communication in general and staff training or at least more experienced staff who could teach the new ones. It did seem to improve as the week went on.But, the biggest thing that will keep us from recommending or going back is the High, and we mean High pressure sales taking a little over 3 hours, half of which was spent telling them we weren't interested with them telling us okay but that we needed to sign some papers before we could leave only to be shuffled to another room/table to be pressured by someone else. After 5 people we found an exit and left. We were also not given our room keys or room location until we agreed to attend this presentation.Drinks were top notch, food above average, housekeeping good, room service quick. The location is pretty remote but taxi into main shopping/dining is about a $20 taxi ride. They do offer a shuttle to one of their other resorts which is walking distance to 5th Ave. Beach much prettier there but drinks are terrible and limited to pina coladas, beer or strawberry daquiris. They don't serve margaritas because they told us they didn't have tequila? There are too many other resorts to pick from.

Reviews.Title: “Overall a good experience”
Reviews.Author: debi10
Reviews.Content: We came to Mexico escaping the coldness of New Jersey only to find cooler temps at the Resort also....Wear your slippers full time in your room as the marlble floors are way too cold and pack a sweatshirt for the evenings because there is "No" heat in the rooms.....the Staff were fantastic and very helpful...A very "new" resort with not much to do except Eat and drink if that's what you're looking for.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome Place”
Reviews.Author: LilyMexico
Reviews.Content: This resorts it's beautiful. People is as helpful as they can be. The best part of this hotel if you have young children it's the Kids Club. The girls on charge of the place are so sweet and so much fun. My children were so happy there. We are definitely coming back!!

Reviews.Title: “This hotel delivered exactly the experience they promised.”
Reviews.Author: mapleleaf4ever
Reviews.Content: We travel as family (of 5) every spring to various southern locations. This is our fourth time to Mexico. This hotel is exactly like it is pictured on the website. Oftentimes pictures can be deceiving and you are unsure about what you will actually find when you get there, but this hotel is as beautiful as it is purported to be. The rooms are large, clean and with the amenities you would expect. The beds and pillows are very comfortable. The grounds are lovely and maintenance staff present but unobtrusive. The staff is warm, friendly and helpful. If you are concerned about timeshare "pushiness", all I can say is I said I would think about joining a tour (decided not to) and we were never asked again. I must make special mention of two people at the hotel who made our stay most enjoyable -- Tony in Entertainment and of course Head Chef Oscar. Tony was an ever friendly face ready for a volleyball game, to take you on a tour or to "hang out" (our oldest boy who is 19 appreciated having someone around his age to show him around). Even my youngest (who was in Kids Club most of the time) was always asking "where's Tony?" because he has such a fun personality. As mentioned in many reviews, Oscar is a terrific personality and a wonderful chef. Our meals, especially in the Italian restaurant, were wonderful. When we introduced ourselves to Oscar (he is ever present in the hotel -- I'm not sure he even sleeps!), and mentioned that he had made a cake for a friend of ours who had visited the hotel that past summer, he took down our information and made a cake for my daughter as well! She was beyond thrilled and I think it made the entire vacation for her -- it's always the little things that do that. You must book the Chef's Table; you will not be disappointed. You do have to purchase a bottle of wine (yes, even though the resort is "all-inclusive) but it was definitely worth it. Seven courses of beautifully cooked, exquisitely presented and chamingly served food was more than worth the small price of the wine. All in all, one of the nicest vacations we've taken in Mexico.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic family getaway”
Reviews.Author: dknj824
Reviews.Content: Just spent a week here with my wife and two kids (8 and 9) and we had the best time. It was away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Cancun, but close to all the activities you'd want to do. The food is the best food we've ever had, from all of the 5 restaurants you could choose from. The deal was incredible! The kids had a great time and are ready to go back. The staff was very warm and friendly and always willing to help us at anytime. The eco-friendly resort is a great place to learn about the environment and the resort's desire to maintain tremendous standards for guests and ensure Mexico's habitats at the same time. We will definitely be back!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely Resort and will only get better!”
Reviews.Author: manchez
Reviews.Content: My wife and I, along with our 4 year-old daughter enjoyed a week at this beautiful resort in early January. All the good things you previously read about Tres Rios is true; great food, top notch rooms, and incredibly friendly staff! Some specifics: Kids Club: Our daugter loved the kids club. The young ladies who ran the club were always smiling and energetic. The club itself is a converted resort room, so nothing too spectacular. I hope management plans to update/expand the club to include and enclosed play area and a miniture water park would be cool. Beach Service: Service in general at the resort was exceptional. However, you never felt completely catered to at the beach. Drink/food service was spotty, often times we had to get our own drinks. Nothing against the servers, the Grill that provides the food is too far from the beach area, and takes quite awhile to get served. Perhaps management can expand to add a snack bar/restroom closer to the beach (perhaps even a swim-up bar at the pool closest to the beach). Pools: The pools were great, always clean and plenty of chairs/lounges to use. Same with the towels, always plentiful. The upper pool is suppose to be an adults only pool, but there were always kids there. No big deal, but they do need to post signs, or reinforce the adults-only theme. Room: The rooms are steller! Can't remember a resort with better rooms, from the design to the towels and sheets! We upgraded to a 1-bedroom, and was lucky enough to get a balcony with a secluded roof deck. There are only 7-8 of these roof decks, so not sure how we got lucky, but loved it! The touch screen for info and room service was not working but no big deal. Spa: The spa is certainly not ready for prime time. It's currently a bunch of converted resort rooms, with no pool/spa/ or real wet/dry sauna. Certainly not worth the $145 for a massage. The resort is currently expanding/builidng the spa area, so once finished should be fine. My wife and I made a spa reservation at the Mandarin Oriental instead and took a cab there ($10). For the $200, we spent 3-4 hours in spa heaven! Food: The food was great as everyone says! My favorite meal was a grilled steak and shrimp with tortialls and quacamole at the outside grill...........with a cervesa! Pure bliss! A shout out to Oscar, such a nice guy who loves what he's doing. Ensures the food you get is top notch and everyone is taken care of. In fact, my 4 year-old was thrilled when one night for dessert, Oscar brought out some bambonies (marshmellows) and charred them at the table! The day before, he asked my daughter what her favorite dessert is, and she said marhsmellows; so the staff went to town and purchased some for her! Very cool! You'll love the reort, and I can imagine it only getting better with time.

Reviews.Title: “Would not go back.”
Reviews.Author: SarahG11
Reviews.Content: We got there just after it rained over night and since a river runs through it there were lots of mosquitos and bugs. The other water was very gross brown. You had to walk down the beach a little bit to get clearer (not clear) water. The fire show was probably the best thing about the place. The resort staff was super friendly.

Reviews.Title: “Probably the best location along the coast”
Reviews.Author: digger17nfld
Reviews.Content: The setting is spectacular, food is very good, four poster beds on the beach with service (beach girl Angelica was great). It is set on 325 acres of natural jungle with three rivers on the property emptying into the sea, great kayaking. Staff were very good well trained, good chef, and top shelf drinks. I have been to Cuba and the DR this is the place to go south. We did a time share presentation which is turning out to be more of a problem then it was worth. We were offer a free massage and manicure along with a couple of other items. At check out the $175.00 massage showed up on the bill, it was not the way I had intended to spend my last morning trying to straighten out the bill. We have since returned home and have been invoiced $49.00 for the manicure. It may seem like small stuff but it not the way to finish a vacation, I was planning a return trip here as we go south every year however I don't like being taken on a "bait and switch", if you are going to do a timeshare presentation for 2 hours of my time the hotel should honor the cetificate that were issued. Note to the Chef Oscar, loved all the food, a la carte, room service, buffet, beach buffet, great presentation, taste, very satisfying. One note that may help for the future is the fries at the outdoor grill were cold everyday, not sure if there is a solution thought I would mention it. Note to management, loved the onsite bike tour however your bikes are in desparate need of upkeep. We walked the beach for a couple of miles, this place is better than any other resort we saw.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing experience”
Reviews.Author: keseygirl
Reviews.Content: I came to this resort with my sister for a week of relaxation and fun. From the moment we stepped out of the shuttle, our stay was out of this world. Our luggage was taken inside by Francisco, who throughout our entire stay was gracious and kind. We were checked in efficiently and quickly by Vanesa and given a welcome "Green Drink"--a concoction of juices that was delicious! Our room was beautiful. Exceptionally clean and comfortable with a lovely view of the ocean and grounds. They have a touch screen system for ordering room service, etc that Francisco explained was not working correctly, but in no way hindered our stay--the phone worked just fine! Housekeeping was consistent, efficient and timely. The food was outstanding. I'm not quite sure where some of these other travelers that did not like the food were eating but it definitely wasn't the same place we were! Chef Oscar Orbe has created a menu throughout the resort that touches on every taste imaginable. The presentation was impeccable and the taste outstanding. Samuel, who I presume is a restaurant manager, was at every meal we had and made sure everything was perfect. We didn't even need menus after a few days because he sent out what he thought we would like and he was always spot on. For lighter fare or more "Americanized" food, there was the Hacienda Grill and Pizza Bar. We ate here during the day and the staff were wonderful--especially Jorge at the Pizza Bar. When we were hanging out on our beach beds on the ocean, Angelica was our server and she was friendly, funny and really made our stay enjoyable. And, 24 hour room service....wow! Never a time when there wasn't food or drink available. The activities are great (and included). We did the Jaguar tour which involved snorkeling down the cenotes and kayaking. Our tour guide, Andy, was great. He was well versed on the property and fun to be around. This was one of the highlights of my stay there. Nightlife activities included Casino Night, Karaoke and Fire shows. Tony, Miguel and Gina were all on hand for these events and made the experience even better. We spent a lot of time in the Victory Sports Bar where we had excellent service (and fun to hang out with) people--Martin and Gabriel, to name a couple. Again, I can't emphasize how great the staff is here. I asked if there was something in the water because I have never stayed somewhere where ALL of the staff seems genuinely happy to have you there. Make sure you tip the staff. Although the "All Inclusive" says tips are included, do yourself (and the amazing staff) a favor and TIP!! The spa was nice--my sister and I both had a treatment done. The prices are a bit more than what we would generally pay in Seattle, but it was a moot point considering where we were! It was well worth it. As for the time share sales push--it is intense--but I only had to tell the concierge one time that I was not interested in pursuing that and was left alone. I think if you just go down when they call you and do not accept any of their "freebies" you will be fine--just remember that this is your trip and going to the presentation is not "required" for your stay. All in all--best trip ever!!!!! Thank you Hacienda Tres Rios for an amazing experience.

Reviews.Title: “Not The Least Bit Disappointed!”
Reviews.Author: lsnhc
Reviews.Content: Let me admit something from the start: We’re spoiled! We have been to Royal Hideaway 9 times, Secrets Capri twice, and the Royal in Cancun once (as well as 3 visits to a wonderful non-all-inclusive, Le Meridien Cancun). All three of these all-inclusives are certainly recognized as among the finest in the Yucatan. Obviously, we love Royal Hideaway!!! This year, given the economy, we opted for something a bit less costly and having done a fair amount of research (primarily on TA) and the availability of some very attractive rates, we opted for HTR. The bottom line: we were definitely not disappointed. While the physical plant is certainly attractive and well maintained (albeit not as opulent as the three AI resorts noted above), what really shines is the staff. Without question, they are unfailingly polite, well intentioned and attentive, and all seem dedicated to making your stay as enjoyable as possible. Oscar, the executive chef, has been mentioned in many of the reviews, and nothing that has been written about him is the least bit exaggerated. Not only does he provide top-notch cuisine, but he seems to work 36 hour days and is never, ever without a smile on his face. One morning, we actually saw him bringing an elderly couple’s suitcases into the lobby for check out! It is almost impossible to describe just what he adds to the experience. Frankly, knowing that he would be here would be reason enough to return! The assistant food and beverage manager, Samuel, was also omnipresent and never less than 150% committed to providing guests with the best service. Carlos, a headwaiter, recognized us at almost every dining venue and never failed to treat us as if we were the only guests. We’d also like to single out several servers: Carlos at the pool, Gregorio, “Ricky Martin,” Miguel, and so many others who added to our enjoyment. As real foodies, we rated the dining experiences to be among the best we have ever encountered at a resort. If there is one failing that is consistent in the restaurants, it is the less than accurate translations of the dishes into English. If someone is not a fan of sophisticated preparations, I can see where they would not be thrilled with the food, especially if they tried to figure out what some of the dishes are based on the “Spanglish” translations! That being acknowledged, we loved the food and would return solely for that reason. Not to be missed is the 7 course chef’s tasting dinner, personally overseen by Chef Oscar in the brightly lit kitchen area adjacent to the prep station. You are required to purchase a somewhat overpriced bottle of wine, but even with that, it was a major bargain and a wonderful experience. One of the things that continually amazed us was that lack of any sense of feeling crowded. This was the first time we have been at an all inclusive (or for that matter, on a cruise) where we did not have to hurry down to the pool to secure lounge chairs. At no time during our weeklong stay was there ever a crowd by either of the pools or on the beach. even though the hotel was full during the last 4 days. The pools were gorgeous and very well laid out. Echoing several other reviewers, while the beach itself was perfectly fine, the water was not very inviting, generally full of vegetation. For us, it was a non-issue, as we were very happy to spend our days at the pool. There were a few downsides that bear mentioning. In several prior reviews, the heavy handed timeshare sales efforts have been mentioned, and there is no question that they really do push sales. When we checked in, I made it clear that we had no interest in buying and assumed that we would not be contacted. I was wrong – at 8:45 on the second morning, we did receive a call but declined the presentation. Having spoken to several other guests, it is clear that HTR has one of the most aggressive timeshare sales programs and while I do understand that it is an integral part of their marketing, it really does detract from its goal to be a world class resort. Several couples we met were actually very upset by how they were treated in the whole timeshare sales process. Some people we spoke with were told that if they did not buy now, they would not be able to return next year (as only owners would be welcomed). Others were shown units “just like the ones that Michael Jordan and the President of Mexico bought.” Obviously, no verification for these claims was available! As we sat around the pool, the primary topic of discussion was who got through the timeshare pitch “unscathed.” We encountered several couples who said they would not return to HTR because of their treatment in the timeshare sales process. In my opinion, it would be a shame if a guest’s lingering memories of their stay was the timeshare interrogation, not the quality of the staff and the facility. My advice to management: Take it down a notch! When a guest says “no,” that should be respected without qualification. Other negatives worth noting: · The air conditioning in the room was, at best, erratic. On some days, we could not get the temperature lower than 74 degrees. On others, we awoke to 66 degree temperatures! To the staff’s credit, as a temporary resolution, they brought in a bedside fan when we could not adequately cool down the room. Many thanks to Hector, the very able concierge, for assisting us in this issue. · The wi-fi was inconsistent almost every day and absolutely unusable during our last day and a half. To those of us that have businesses or family that rely on our ability to communicate, even during vacations, this is a significant problem. Again, this has been chronicled in several other posts. · The “Ice” system (touch screen, in-room resort info) did not work for the entire time we were there. · As previously noted, the hair dryers in the room are absolutely useless. Be sure to bring your own if you require one. Also, if you have the requisite number of electronic “toys” that need charging (a couple of cell phones, a laptop, camera, etc.), bring some multiple outlets, as there are not a lot of really accessible outlets in the room. · Entertainment and activities are, at best, so-so, and with the lack of the “Ice” system, I think that the dispersal of information regarding activities was hampered. · Spa treatments are absurdly expensive. 55 minute massages range from $120 - $140. Even the spa Le Meridien in Cancun was significantly less costly. Don’t be afraid to ask about discounts, as there are a variety available. This being acknowledged, the massages my wife and I had were absolutely wonderful. · The fitness center is adequate, but unless you are prepared to get up early in the morning, there are no exercise classes or aquatic classes during what could be termed “civilized” hours! If you are seeking a vacation rife with nightlife, shopping, etc., HTR is probably not the best choice. A cab ride into Playa del Carmen is approximately $25 round trip, so frequent jaunts into town are just not practical. If, on the other hand, you are looking for a place to just relax and recharge, be treated amazingly well, and enjoy really wonderful food and service, there is very little not to like. The graciousness even extended to check out. As we had a late flight, we were able to stay until 2:30, well past the 11:00 check out time. A simple request to Hector at the concierge desk provided us with an empty suite at 2:00 so we could shower and dress prior to leaving. In summary, keep your distance from the time share folks and enjoy a simply wonderful vacation!

Reviews.Title: “Just what the Doctor ordered !”
Reviews.Author: MountainDude
Reviews.Content: My wife and I needed 3 days of peace, pampering and perfection. Hacienda Tres Rios was just what the Doctor ordered! This was our third stay in the first year of the resort's life. From the moment we arrived and were greeted by Jesus, "Welcome Home", ushered to the front desk and in our room in under 15 minutes, we could easily see why HTR was voted in the Top 10! Then off to lunch at the grill, great food, great service. Chef Oscar has his staff ready to serve and eager to please. The afternoon on a beach bed, with wonderful service from Angelica. A short stay in the hot-tub and the off to a fantastic oriental experience for dinner. Alfredo was their to greet us and treat us like royalty. Food was extraordinary. After dinner, we headed to the bar in the international buffet, where Trefelio, created the best cappuccino martini my wife had ever tasted. On to the sports bar for Karaoke. Entertainment Director "Dr. Hector", has something happening all the time. Senior Samuel, is always there at the restaurants to insure a great experience for all. We loved all the varieties, Italian, Oriental, the Grill, but , my personal favorite is breakfast at the international buffet. Each morning we were greeted with a big smile and "Buenas Dias " by Gregorio and had a wonderful selection of items to choose from. During our stay we had numerous conversations with other guests about their stay and other resorts they had visited. While we all agreed that each resort has its pluses and minuses, we discovered one theme about HTR that was re-occurring. The property is just the right size, the location in a 300 acre preserve eco-friendly area is perfect. The rooms, pools and amenities are accessible even when the property is full. The food selection offers something for everyone. And yes they are still working on the beach area, but overall this is a true 5 Star property. The big difference between HTR and any other Maya resort are the PEOPLE ! When that terrible moment of having to head back to the airport and the real world, Michael left us with" See you when you come back home". We already miss our HTR family and do look forward to returning again soon.

Reviews.Title: “Absolute Fantabulous!”
Reviews.Author: luv2sun4tans
Reviews.Content: A beautiful resort with plenty of room at the pool and restaurants. The front desk kept saying the hotel was full but my husband and I didn't see any evidence of it! We never had to worry about finding a pool chair. The best part for us was not having to wait in the stupid reservation line every morning for the speciality restaurants. We just showed up whenever, wherever and had great food! Food: We didn't feel like the buffet food was ever hot. They had a great deal of variety but the warming lights just kept it warm - not steaming. We feel like they need steaming trays under the food. We always found something we liked. Our favorite was Asian night and the Hacienda Grill by the pool. They are EXCELLENT. The upstairs mexican restaurant has steak that melts in your mouth too! Entertainment: The hotel doesn't have a bunch of young staffers running around blowing whistles and making people take shots. It was quiet and relaxing. There were nightly shows - the Fire show is the best. The hotel management is wonderful and very helpful. They treat their staff very well. Each night the waiters would have a team meeting and then put their hands in the middle of a circle and chant to "pump them up" before their shift. Please get to know your waiter at the pool, the towel girl, the waiter who serves your food. They are very nice and want to please you. We tipped every day. A dollar goes a long way. What's $50-$75 in weekly tips after you have spent thousands on your trip? You'll get better service and get to practice your spanish. I didn't like the hair dryers in the rooms. Wierd and techno looking and didn't dry very well or fast. I strongly recommend bringing one from home. Extras: Sign up for the bicycle tour of the property. It is easy and informative. Everyone looks great in a helmet! Wade in the cenotes. Beautiful and clear. Its easy to kayak up stream. There are cool looking red crabs along the way.

Reviews.Title: “nice place, horrible management”
Reviews.Author: flyfisherBc
Reviews.Content: Our experience at the Tresrios was a nightmare. We got suckered into looking into a timeshare. We were promised a nice breakfast and were told to have an open mind. We did have an open mind throughout the whole presentation which was suppose to be only 90 mins with absolutely no pressure. It turned out to be about 5 hours! 'Michael' was the guy we dealt with. He started off as being nice but quickly turned nasty. He said all the right things he was trained to say to get a sale. After we said we needed some time to think about the offer, we were hastily passed to some other guy and then the pressure was increased. After we politely said we 'just want to go home', a loudmouth French Canadian came into the room. It was so annoying. We just wanted to get out of there. After asking many times to leave, we were finally allowed. My wife was crying after this experience. I personally cannot believe this kind of place exists. The people that run this place are evil. I would definitely not recommend this place to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic First Time Experience, Exceptional Resort”
Reviews.Author: vernon4
Reviews.Content: Where to start? After much research, review and consideration of where to stay for our very first trip to Mexico, we hit the jackpot where resorts are concerned. The moment we arrived at the resort, we were treated like royalty. The staff delivered exceptional service right from the concierge, front desk, waiters/waitresses, housekeeping and recreation and management staff. Our room was gorgeous, clean and had very comfortable beds with featherbed toppers. Pillows were great, and you could also choose any type necessary. All rooms had view of beach/pool area as hotel is in horseshoe shape. Food. As we booked all inclusive package, all food, drinks were included. Their buffet each day had a variety of food for all tastes . All - a la carte restaurants were also included and did not have to be reserved. Each night, you could try different food, mexican, italian, seafood, steak, or the buffet which was very good. World class iron chef Oscar was always available to speak with or seen walking around resort ensuring everyone received first class service. Wait staff exceptionally efficient and polite. The beach and pool area is very beatiful..daytime activities include daily beach volleyball with Andy, great guy ! bocci ball, soccer , spanish lessons, snorkelling, kayaking, different eco adventure all free as resort has its own eco park. Nightly entertainment included kareoke night, casino, Mayan show, fire show, and more usually run by our favorite people Roberto, Tony and Andy ( they made our experience very memorable). Shopping: Playa Del Carmen is a short taxi ride from resort. Hotel staff always arranged taxi and let us know what it would cost before we left. average $15 u.s. one way. Great shopping in Playa, you get a great Mexican flavour. Great nightlife also, hotel staff chaparoned an excursion to a nightclub and ensured we got back safely to resort in taxi, much appreciated boys!!! All in all, there may be other good resorts out there, but it will be very hard to beat the great experience we had at Hacienda Tres Rios. Top notch all the way! We will definately go back. Thank you.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous”
Reviews.Author: JAGLOVE
Reviews.Content: Where do we begin??? Hacienda Tres Rios met all of our expectations and beyond. The service is what we feel really sets this resort apart. From the moment you arrive at Cacun Airport and are greeted by their taxi escort staff to the moment you leave the hotel and are wished farewell by the concierge/lobby staff, you feel like royalty! The food is superb and the staff stop at nothing to make sure you are satisfied with every meal you are served. We would like to recognize the folliowng servers who were exceptional : Yarah, our concierge; Miguel, Frankie, Francisco, Aris, and our sales staff Charlotte, who sucessfully sold us a lifetime of vacation. The studio was very spacious and comfortable. The pools, beach, manicured grounds and endless ammenities were spectacular. We can't wait to return next year with our children! Thanks for the wonderful memories, celebratign our 6th wedding anniversary, as well as making our first of many vacations at Tres Rios so awesome. Muchos Gracias! Jeff & Gail Gimborys

Reviews.Title: “Nice resort, beware of what you are told”
Reviews.Author: Mexicotravelerdenver
Reviews.Content: We traveled with friends to the Tres Rios resort. This was a promotion trip that our friends had invited us to. My wife and I travel extensively in Mexico 4-5 times a year. We are ok with our Spanish and can interact with most residents. We found the resort very nice and most people very accomodating. The activities are really cool...from kayaking to sailing, exploring Cenote's and bike riding or just hanging on the beach. We found the pool to be another awesome place to catch sun and have a cerveza. We attended the promotional seminar and even though we were not interested did not think it was high pressure and everyone was polite. We were able to sign for all food and drink and this was included in our package. We were invited to attend the Chef's table and were told that we could pick any bottle of wine on a particular list for 16.00US. My friend and I signed up for ourselves and our spouses, and reiterated the price for the bottle of wine. We verifed that the cost of the wine was once again 16.00US (twice before we picked our bottles). I drink roughly a bottle of wine every night in the US so I was surprised at the offer. It is unusual to find CA wine in Mexico so I was very impressed with the offer! We concluded our selections and the next night attended the Chef's table. The executive chef, Oscar wasgreat, he spent time with us and explained everything he was serving and we had a wonderful time sipping wine and lauging and eating. The rest of our stay was equally enjoyable...until WE CHECKED OUT! My friend and I had arranged transportation in advance and went to check out 15 minutes before our scheduled departure. This is when our enjoyable trip changed.....we both noticed we were charged $150.00US each for our bottles of wine!!!! Of course we questioned the charges and were told that we were never told this. I was in shock, they ushered our concierge (Helen) over to the front desk to rudley reiterate that we were never told this, funny thing is she is not the one who told us this...so why was she in our face? Then another employee came to the front desk (our shuttle had already left) and said she was the one who took our wine order and never told us this! Then proceeded to tell us that employee's would have to pay the difference if we did not pay the tab and they were unable to check us out of the hotel. My friend and I were not very happy, where or how could we come up with such a ridicoulous story! My spanish is not that bad to misunderstand such an offer and the fact both my friend and I heard the exact same offer! We were embarresed and felt like the staff was accusing us of coming up with this ridicolus story to get out of paying for the wine!!!!! No offer was made for the misunderstanding. We closed our tabs, had to wait another half hour for another shuttle and were disappointed that our wonderful trip came to an end on such a sour note!

Reviews.Title: “Pattermac - Great adventure echo type holiday, beach not great, accommodation and hospitality excellent.”
Reviews.Author: PATTERMAC
Reviews.Content: The hotel is situated in the jungle/bush about 20 minutes north of Playa Del Carmen. It is new, striking and different. It is echo based and and geared towards adventure rather than your standard beach holiday. The beach was not as large as others and the water dirty due to the nearby rivers. The pool areas at the hotel are outstanding and made up for the deficient beach. The pool water temperature was perfect and there were ample chairs and umbrellas around the pool. There were many free tours at the hotel which included Sensorary Experience, bicycle tours, snorkelling, kayaking and swimming in cenates. The type of people there were excellent and we got along with most, making some good friends. Rooms were excellent in all aspects and so was the food quality and variety. Entertainment was provide at night and was perfect Casino Evening, Karoke, Mayan Dancing, Tequila tasting etc. It was there but did not dominate. The "Time Share Presentation" was pushed on each guest for the reward of a free trip. This was at least 2 hrs. As owners of a Luxury Junior Suite we feel that we got fair value at $2,200 for a week including all-inclusive versus the open market price of $3,500 if booked as a hotel (10 visits to break even). Our complaints are as follows. The resort is a bit isolated and requires a taxi to get to Playa. A shuttle is included in some of the all-inclusive deals. The beach is not the best but OK. The hairdryers are sub-standard. The "honeymoon spa" deal was explained as a $210 minus $30 discount for 2 people but when it came to paying it was this much each which was a bit expensive and not expected.

Reviews.Title: “wow, awesome”
Reviews.Author: CanadaWhistler
Reviews.Content: What a place from the moment we walked in the door and were shown our room, to the pool service thank you Ambrose. There are no complaints to be made. The food was amazing thanks to an amazing team in the kitchen it was like eating in a restaurant each night, infact morning and mid day, not at an all inclusive resort. If you are lucky enough to stay here and a young man called Sam Vargas offers to choose your meal for you, allow him. His gracious spirit and fantastic advice made us think we were 2 individuals not just Hotel guests. Fron hi friendly smile aorund the Hotel to his advice for meals. Thanks Sam. Infact all the staff were great and we can not wait until we visit the Hotel, the pools, the staff, the restaurants oh and the area again, because we are already counting the sleeps! Tres Rios you have added a season to the Four Season resorts, we call you the Five Seasons!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Paradise on earth”
Reviews.Author: SunnyMojito
Reviews.Content: Very short review: Just go!!! Another trip advisor user said about Hacienda Tres Rios: “if you don’t like this place check your pulse”. Well I must agree 100% with that statement because if you’re normal, you won’t want to go back home after spending time at this immaculate resort. Very long review My husband and I decided to go on a couple’s vacation for the first time in many years (and without our 15 month old baby). We were looking for a relaxing and luxurious retreat to make it worth our while and that’s exactly what we got. We are in our early thirties and are both well traveled. I’ve been using tripadvisor.com for years now to avoid making huge vacation mistakes but this is the first time I actually take the time to write a review because I felt like this place deserved one. It’s a pretty long read so I broke it down into a few categories. Rooms The rooms all have ocean view, are pretty big in size, extremely comfortable and rival those of any expensive luxurious hotel around the world. Before this place, I had never heard of all inclusive resorts offering 7 different types of pillows to the guests. There are bathrobes and the alarm clock has an I-pod adapter. There is also a flat screen TV as well as a touch screen monitor on which you can order room service, check out the restaurants and menus or even surf the web for free. Our mini fridge was filled with beer, soda and water and was restocked daily. There is a great turn down service…and if you think you’ve seen nice swan towel creations on vacation before, wait till you see what crazy towel sculptures they come up with daily. Beach The beach is beautiful and decent sized. There are about two dozen beach beds with canopies. We were able to find one on any given day and most importantly at any time of day. They are extremely comfortable and always clean since they seem to change the sheets and pillow covers on them every day. The ocean right in front of the hotel looks murky and dark on windier days and hotel staff explained it was a result of the organic residues left in the ground from the red and white mangroves which used to grow on that beach. Workers clean up the beach daily and we swam in the warm ocean almost every day. It doesn’t get really deep and the bottom is clean. Look at my beach pictures you’ll see people swimming in the ocean. We spent most of our time swimming and tanning where the first two rivers meet the ocean. The water there is much warmer and see-through. If you pick the last beds on the left near the water sports you can swim in the first river while keeping an eye on your things. The 3 rivers There are 3 pristine rivers on the property and the first two are easily accessible. You can reach the third river’s entrance by kayaking in the ocean along the beach. We made it a point to kayak up all three rivers and they’re simply stunning. Once you’re deep in the mangroves, you might need some bug spray while kayaking. We snorkeled down the first two rivers many times during our stay. Because the current gently brings you down to the ocean, you don’t even have to swim while enjoying the different types of fish. These rivers are crystal clear and feel warmer than the ocean. (see river and cenote pics). The pools & Hot tubs The pools are beautiful and huge and have many “tanning islands” on which nobody tans because the water is freeeezzzing! Many Mexican resorts don’t seem to heat their pools in winter and this is a shame because they’re crystal clear and inviting. They were apparently too refreshing for the kids as well because most of them used to end up in the 3 hot tubs on a daily basis which I found kind of ironic. Water sports There were hobie cats and kayaks on the beach. You can kayak up and down the rivers or in the ocean and also snorkel down the rivers. They also have a few canoes to use in the river surrounding the resort. As for other sports, I believe they had pilates classes, bicycle tours, yoga as well as jogging in the morning. I’m pretty sure there was a gym but we were way too busy overindulging in alcohol and food to check it out… The food We are very picky eaters (my husband is Italian) and we loved the food at Tres Rios. The food was very high quality and there was always something great to eat. Their wood burning oven pizzas are amazing and we never waited more than 15 minutes for them. You can order them from your room or even from the beach beds. Our favourite restaurant was by far the Hacienda grill, where my husband enjoyed rib eye steak almost ever other night until we found out about the lobster tails. You can have rock lobster at any of their restaurants for no additional fees but I believe you have to ask the Maître D one night in advance for it. They don’t advertise it so we found out about the lobster only on our 6th night, almost by accident because our neighbours were eating them….so you’re welcome ;)! The grouper at the grill was also amazing for supper as well as their stuffed chicken breast at lunch time. The deserts at the Italian restaurant tasted really rich and authentic. The Mexican restaurant was too “high end” to our taste, probably because we were expecting more of a Taco Bell type of menu. We did enjoy their Mexican welcome party under the stars on Saturday night. Try to do the “chef’s table” special dinner it is really worth it. The meal is included for the chef’s supper but not the wine so it will set you back a minimum of about 65$ for one bottle, but the 7 course refined meal is really worth it. You get to enjoy this meal inside the main kitchen and Oscar, the head chef, explains every dish in detail. (see pictures) Internet In addition to the touch screen monitor on which you can surf the web in your room, there is wi-fi internet access on the resort. You can also catch many neighbouring resorts’ networks. We needed a more stable connection so we unplugged the wireless modem in the room (situated under the night table) and connected our laptop directly to the hotel’s network. Connection was good enough to skype our family every day from the room for free (with video). There were also two laptops in the exit lounge for guests to use and they were always available. Check-in / check-out We arrived at the hotel on a Tuesday afternoon and the check-in went very smoothly. We were then introduced to our “private concierge” who explained many interesting aspects of the resort but then proceeded in trying to have us participate in a timeshare presentation. If you can afford to buy property in Mexico, by all means, get informed about the place because they will compensate you for your time by giving you free massages, meals, activities, car rentals and so on. In our case, since we cannot afford to buy property in Mexico at the moment, we respectfully (but firmly) declined. Who wouldn’t want to call this place home… We opted not to waste the salesperson’s time as well as cutting down on our own precious vacation time so we said no and they never brought it up again. Check-out was a breeze as well (less than 5 minutes). Staff No matter how nice of a property Tres Rios is, it is the staff who ultimately makes it a 5 star resort. Everybody will go out of their way to help you and get you what you need. Our favourite waiter was hands down Carlos; who from the moment he learned we like chocolate dipped strawberries, brought them to us wherever we seemed to be on the resort and sometimes more than once a day! The best margarita award goes to Efrain when he’s at the main restaurant bar, to Cruz at the beach bar, and to our friend Abenamar at the Grill. Nice folks at the entertainment also with Tony, Miguel, Sergio and Andrea. Nightlife / Party Even at full capacity, this resort feels very exclusive because there are less than 300 rooms. Most guests seem to be looking for a calming and relaxing vacation. The average age is also higher than most resorts so this is not the place to come to if you wish to party hard every night. They organize trips to Playa del Carmen a few nights a week for guests who wish to go clubbing downtown. The sports bar at the resort is very family oriented and never turns into a real party. We were probably the youngest couple vacationing there and still managed to have a great time every night with the other guests and the staff, but ultimately we got what we went there for: comfort, peace and quiet.

Reviews.Title: “So Relaxing, Gorgeous, and left Stuffed!!”
Reviews.Author: Traveling4Fun_n_Work
Reviews.Content: I had the opportunity to stay here for 4 nights after a few business days in Cancun. The resort is simply Gorgeous. The Staff was always very friendly and provided excellent service. I think everyone says it but Chef Oscar is simply the best. His meal preparation and attention to detail, plus the fact that he will come out and speak with you. I've never seen that before in an All Inclusive Resort. Food was just AMAZING. I ate way too much! The tour of the grounds and nursery is great. I choose to snorkel down the Cenote which was a very unique experience since it's Fresh Water. Definitely bring Mosquito spray, as they are everywhere in the Mangrove's. The water is not quite the same color as I've seen when I've stayed in Cozumel. Beach though is really nice white sand, and not rocky like I experienced in Cozumel. The Spa was also quite nice, I enjoyed a Hot Stone Massage. Don't miss out on the "Sensation" Experience conducted by the Shaman, totally a unique experience. The Beds are very comfy and I think I slept better at Hacienda Tres Rios than in my own bed. Attention by the maids was always very good, and I enjoyed the nightly turn down with yummy chocolates or desserts. I can't wait to go back when I have at least a full week to really enjoy all the Resort has to offer. Next time I'll be bringing the Family!

Reviews.Title: “Can I live at Hacienda Tres Rios?”
Reviews.Author: babooshka2
Reviews.Content: I met a group of friends at Hacienda just for a fun getaway. we chose it because it was brand new and the special price was in our range. OMG it was heavenly! very relaxing and we felt so cared for. the staff was friendly, the concierge was really good at giving us tips for the events of the day, every time we had a question someone answered with kindness. even the tour guides seemed to enjoy their job - they were really funny and kept us all laughing. OK so the food was sinful, tortillas made fresh right in front of us at breakfast, serenades at dinner while we ate delicious food. The buffet had something for even the picky eaters in our group. I want to live there so I can be at the ocean every day and hang out until the orchids bloom.

Reviews.Title: “Never Again!!!!”
Reviews.Author: Workhardtravelhard
Reviews.Content: The Hecienda Tres Rio's? Ah, yeah, where do I start? First, I'm a timeshare owner who searches for nice places to stay via a trade through the timeshare. Our search came up with The Hecienda. We said sure, everywhere else we ever stayed was very nice and thought this would be the same, however we decieded not to take the all inclusive ($120.00 per day per person, $240.00 per couple) to only find we we're going to pay that price anyway, and be treated like a redheaded stepchild. The meals were, per person $30.00 for breakfast, $40.00 for lunch and $60.00 for dinner......yes thats $260.00 per couple for food ,and drinks we're extra. The resort is very secluded, so unless you had a rental car and wanted to drive out ever 4 hours on a 1 hour trip to get food, you felt very trapped to purchase there plan or there very high priced meals. No meal especially there's was worth that kind of money, although I do admit the meals were good, it was usually only buffet, there were a few al carte, however they seemed to close down very early. If you did'nt get the all inclusive you'd find it very hard to find a waiter by the pool, and when you did, and ask for a certain beer, it seemed that beer was never available.... you we're brought a cheaper beer while your all inclusive neighbor was brought the beer you just requested. (with the lime). then on several occasions I had to correct the waiters for beer I was charged and never ordered. It was clear to me that there was no free stay with a timeshare trade, that you thought you were promised when purchased (other than an exchange fee). You will still pay the nightly rate through the all inclusive package or the high price of meals if not all inclusive. The beach we so love to see( The Crystal blue water where you can swim and snorkel) is not at this location. the water is very dirty, and lots of stuff floating around. No one I saw was ever swimming in it, only at the pool! The moat around the resort had an oder, all the time. The water was clear yet smelled. The rooms we're very clean, and the beds were very comfortable, I can't say anything bad about the accomodations other than the hairdryers suck, so bring your own, and the toilet room has no fan, and an open vent in the door, so turn the TV up loud or make others leave the room if you have business to do. Oh yeah, it's an eco park also, so the fridges in the rooms are not cold. Have to save electricity!
