Every beer I had during my stay was warm,(at around $6.00 per warm beer) since I was not all inclusive, however if you were the warm beer was free. I hate to say anything bad about anyplace, however when you work hard and want to get away and forget about everything for a week, enjoy yourself with no stress or worrys, maybe you should look somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, Relaxing Stay with Amazing Food”
Reviews.Author: wendy4810
Reviews.Content: Wow, what a great trip. First let me say that the food in every restaurant on the property was some of the best I've ever been served including the many fine restaurants I've eaten at that were not affiliated with any hotels (stand alone restaurants). Chef Oscar designs entire new menus in each restaurant every 6 months. Whenever possible, the foods are authentic to each corresponding cuisine. Everything is prepared fresh. At breakfast in the Mexican restaurant, tortillas were being prepared right in front of us from a batch of fresh dough, pressed on an small cast iron tortilla press and then thrown in a skillet with toppings we chose added. The grounds were beautiful from the hotel, to the pools to the beach to the plant nursery and surrounding protected lands with walking paths and cenotes. Everything is maintained with great care and respect for the land. Small touches were ever present from different authentic mexican candies on our pillow each night to our pad of butter in one restaurant wrapped in a green leaf. Little touches that showed how much thought was put into the entire operation. All the hotel staff was friendly, courteous and eager to help in any way they could. The rooms were good size and spotless. Our stay was completely relaxing and worry free. I would gladly return and enjoy another memorable vacation at this beautiful hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Family Fun and Real Relaxation”
Reviews.Author: goseminoles
Reviews.Content: We stayed at 3rios with our 3 kids, 10, 14,18. To my surprise everyone was happy with the variety of activities and swiming pools. My wife and I were very happy with the beds on the beach and the level of service. The variety of the food and the quality was very good for an all inclusive resort. We were also very surprised at the quality and variety of the drinks. We did notice that not all of the resorts amenities were finished, and would liked to have seen a better quality workout facility and spa. We were very concerned about the beach based on other reviews, and noticed that it is better in some areas than others and they still have work on finishing it. My kids had a great time and we plan to return when they have everything finished. Great Rooms, Great Staff, Great Food.

Reviews.Title: “Highly overrated”
Reviews.Author: atticusfinchMontreal
Reviews.Content: First and foremost, it started with a lie. That we would enjoy the "calm turquoise water of the carribean ocean" at HTR. But how could we when the water is black, muddy and full of seaweed and other debris? The ocean IS the main attraction for many travelers from the north countries and they should state it clearly on their website that you can't (and won't) swim in the ocean. The mangrove by the side is also in a shockingly bad shape. So is the "canal" surrounding the resort. It has a bad odor and when we were there, it was cold. I can't imagine the smell when it's hot. Then, all areas are closed and it's freezing everywhere because of the clim' . Again, it was already cold outside, why freeze the whole damn place? It does not make sense. We tried to eat at the grill outside. They told us "we are closed" and refused to serve us even tough many people were still eating. Again, we paid for the "all included" package. Seemed to me the all included does include the "all" only when it's a convenience for the hotel. The employes were very nice, but no one seemed to know who the responsible person was. They all said "you have to ask this other person" for everything and it was like beeing trapped in a Kafka novel. Then the food. Listen. It's ridiculously pretentious and still not good. Tempura over mashed potatoes and black beans? With a plum sauce so sweet it was like sirup. This was supposed to be the fancy "à la carte" restaurant. We laughed and would have much much preferred a simpler, more authentic mexican cuisine. We tried to forget about it at the bar. Enters "the sport bar". Kids everywhere over the pool table and not a barman to be found! We tough it was the kids playground. No. It was the bar. Still, no barman. We frantically searched for a decent drink. Anything would have do. We encountered two bored pizza men, and a terrified (and very angry...) mother "mapache" with her babies. We were the only ones there and it was freezing. Again. We went to bed hungry, cold, and alas, very sober. We nicknamed the place "the mall" because it felt like beeing trapped in a mall, expensive, luxurious, mais sans âme. No soul. The beds were excellent. At last something good. We slept and we tried to meet with someone, anybody, who could refund us. "Ah no, I'm afraid everyone is gone for the week-end, it will have to wait until monday". On monday, they did refund the remaining part of our stay. But not the four days that we lost, waiting for somebody to pay attention. So no... even if the hotel is decent, never again.

Reviews.Title: “Beautful place...terrible food...inconsistent service”
Reviews.Author: gocards166
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went to Hacienda Tres Rios for our honeymoon. The trip did not start off well even before we left. We tried to arrange private transportation for over a month via emails and telephone calls with no result until the day before we left (our wedding). Overall the resort is beautiful but it's obvious that the resort is still working out kinks being that it's a relatively new resort. Our first impressions were great with a grand entrance and a very friendly welcoming staff. However, when we got to our room we had no type of touch screen or guide to tell us where everything was, no cable TV, and the room was not fully decorated since it was in one of the newer sections of the resort. When we asked the front desk (Hector) about why we didn't have these things it seemed as though we were "inconveniencing" him. This seemed to be pretty consistent throughout the week. At one point the staff actually accused us of stealing one of their DVD's because the case had two pages for DVD's and it only came with one...which didn't even work by the way. One thing we were looking forward to was the all-inclusive food and alcohol. The alcohol was great with numerous high end liquors, but my wife and I are not big drinkers so we didn't necessarily get our moneys worth on this. The food, however, was downright bad. We tried nearly every restaurant and the food was either cold, luke warm, or not what we ordered and had to be sent back. The only meals that we even looked forward to eating was the omelette station at breakfast and pizza at lunch/dinner...mostly because they were hot! The best food we had was McDonalds that we had our cab driver take us to on the way to Tulum...and I strongly dislike McDonalds! Activities at the resort were great. Kayaking was awesome, snorkeling was fun, and there was always plenty of other activities going on. The pool staff was sometimes great and sometimes not so great. We tipped 50 pesos everyday and sometimes we got our drinks or food right away and sometimes we got our drinks and food 45 minutes later. Overall, I don't think I'd recommend Hacienda Tres Rios. For as much as we paid I would have wanted better food and definitely some more friendly assistance.

Reviews.Title: “Treated Royally by all, left feeling like family!”
Reviews.Author: septembermarch
Reviews.Content: This was our first time at Playa Del Carmen and we were a little anxious due to the beginning of the H1N1 scare... after all we were travelling with an 87 year old and a 6 year old. Hacienda Tres Rios was a wonderful place to relax and unwind. What we did find was a great resort! What we did not find was anyone sick anywhere. The staff could not have been kinder! The service everywhere was a treat, and the view from our room was peaceful. When we arrived we were greeted with champagne and a great room. We were "invited" to a sales presentation which we turned down and were approached 2 other times and politely declined. During our stay the First Lady of Mexico arrived via helicopter so there was security detail everywhere. It was exciting to meet Senora de Calderon and one of the resort owners' daughters we had seen on a YouTube video previously. Even with all the hoopla surrounding her visit we still felt staff attention to detail. While there we did meet several families with fluorescent wristbands and they explained to us that they were there as part of a timeshare and that not everyone there had the same benefits that we had. We were never asked to wear tacky wristbands. Our son enjoyed the kid's club even if there were only two other little girls there. They played together well at the cenotes, made their own pizzas at the outdoor pizza oven, enjoyed making kiddie cocktails, and learning Spanish from the staff. We also enjoyed the Mayan cultural show. The resort used to be a water park but was closed down due to drugs. After being refurbished it is now touted as an ecological resort. The tour into their natural cenotes on site was refreshing and river canoeing was fun also. Communicating with colleagues and the office back home via phone would have been costly and you cannot use a phone card at the resort. Our choices were either to use the internet at the business suite or go into the town of Playa del Carmen and use a payphone with our calling card. Most often we stayed in touch using their free internet. Please do not pay the asking price for a taxi ride into charming Playa del Carmen, bargain a little and have fun with it. We made friends with a great taxi driver and the next day for $40 including a tip we had him as our local tour guide for the entire day. He took us to some beautiful cenotes used by the locals, a super exclusive beach with no hotels around and only a bar, and showed us how the real Mayans live- a world away from the luxuries of Hacienda Tres Rios. The food was good, but the service was better. Everyone giving the hotel a review raves about Oscar the head chef but we never met him, maybe he was too busy with all the Presidential guests. We tried the cricket empanadas upstairs in the Mexican rest. but enjoyed eating under the stars with the Mariachi band, by the pool probably the best. Speaking of the pools, they were always very clean and lovely. As others have stated the view of the ocean was murky, but they told us they are working on this. We thought the pools made up for the lack of beach. Would we return to Hacienda Tres Rios? In a heartbeat. FYI we booked with a travel agency "Book-it.com" and later discovered that this agency is owned by the wife of one of the resort owners. I guess the introductory hotel rates we received reflect that.

Reviews.Title: “The best resort we have stay at!”
Reviews.Author: GinaTay
Reviews.Content: First and foremost: I am always apprehensive of any reviews by a person who only has one contribution. While the review may be legitimate chances are that it is bogus. Remember that when you are looking for a resort. Check-in: Our check in did not go very well. There was one person working at the desk and he did not seem to really know what was going on. We booked two rooms, both junior suites, one with a jacuzzi. We didn’t really want two rooms but I was told that I had to have two rooms because my teenage sons were considered adults. My calls kept getting dropped when I tried to call and confirm so I used the “live person” on their website to confirm. The person running the front desk said that we only had one room. I questioned it and explained what I was told. Then he told me that we could have two rooms but there weren’t any jacuzzi rooms available and there weren’t any adjoining rooms available. I was a little upset that we had confirmed yet our rooms were not available. Additionally, when I confirmed I was told that that our rooms would be adjoining. I showed him the printout of the conversation and he made a copy of it. Still we didn’t get the rooms we had confirmed and we were told that we would be moved to the correct rooms in the morning. The next morning I stopped at the front desk and asked if our rooms were ready. He said that I needed to wait until more people checked-out. He told me that he would call me when the rooms were ready. Later I stopped in the late afternoon and I was again told that they would call me because my rooms were not ready. That evening my husband and I decided that the rooms were fine and that we would unpack and stay. I never informed the front desk that we were going to stay in the rooms. Yet, I never got a call all week to move to the rooms that I was promised. Additionally, we weren’t given the all-inclusive bracelets or the welcome package. While we were waiting for the front desk to find a room for us we were entertained by a church choir. They were really good and they were singing Christmas music. Additionally, there was a waiter making rounds offering us appetizers and drinks. That was a really nice touch. When we got to the room the bus boy basically bolted. I didn’t mind because I figured we could navigate pretty well on our own. We could not find the menu for room service. I called room service and requested a menu. He acted surprised and said that we should have gotten a black book. Shortly after my kids discovered the computer and saw that it had all the information that we needed. It was touch screen and we were able to order room service online. Way cool. Additionally, anything and everything I wanted to know about the resort was there. The rooms: They were very nice and clean. We liked our view of the moat/river and pools with the ocean further away. The marble floors are very pretty and the beds are very comfortable. The linen, towels, stocked fridge, and room service added a lot of value to our room. The shower, double sinks, and closed in toilet were very nice. The blow dryer is worthless though. Bring you own FOR SURE. The food: The food was ok. Disclaimer: we are very fussy and normally are content with plain grilled food so maybe it was too involved for our tastes. Our favorite place to eat was at the Hacienda Grill. Once we figured out how to special order everything plain we liked the food. At the buffet we struggled a little but we were all able to find something that we would eat. The quality was very good. What I really missed, and normally saves us at a buffet, was a full salad bar. Normally, there was lettuce and some green beans, and not much more. We really missed that. After a couple of days we learned to order things that weren’t on the menu. The pizza was ok. Housekeeping: I never did figure out their schedule. I know that they made several rounds to clean, offer fresh towels, toiletries, and refill the mini-bar. They did a really thorough job of cleaning and even folded my kids clothes! Also, much to my dismay, my teenage boys left out expensive electronics more than once and we did not have any problems. The pools: They were a little chilly but better than other places we have been to. In the past we have got to places where no one was in the pool—there were people in the pools—including my family. The chairs were very comfortable. There really wasn’t a problem with finding a chair most of the time. Because we are a family of four I did start saving our chairs so we could sit together. We used the beach beds a few times too and thought it was great. While at the pool and beach there is always someone making rounds bringing food and drinks. I don’t know if it was the language barrier or the waiter’s faulty memory but I am pretty sure that we were given someone else’s food and drinks more than once. Actually, my son’s accidentally got spiked drinks a couple of times. No worries, my husband and I were glad to take them. HA! Beach: The beach itself is great. From the white sand to the beds and chairs it was very clean and well serviced. But what I love most about a beach is the ocean water and that is where the beach stops short. I have been told that they are working on it. Apparently, the mangroves were damaged in the Wilma hurricane causing dirt to wash up to the Hacienda beach. Additionally there is a lot of seaweed (they told me that it wasn’t seaweed—fine there is something weed-like and vine-y that washes up from the ocean). Hacienda’s beach is literally black from the dirt and full of a “weed-like vine-y material”. We only saw people in the water once. On our first day there were two younger kids having a great time. We did go through the cenote which is very clear to the ocean. We were able to walk forever and still not be waist deep. It was very pretty. No one used the hoby cats at all. They were in good shape and I was told that someone would take us if we asked. I didn’t see the canoe’s get used very often either. It is possible that people don’t know that they are available. We wanted to try the hoby cats but we didn’t know who to ask. We talked ourselves out of it because it was very windy anyway. Cenote: it was clear but there was a layer of debris and oil. TV: The TV’s were out the entire time. Normally, we go hard all day and go back to the room and watch a movie and the news in the evening. We really missed the TV’s. The concierge had a lot of movie. Because the whole resort was without cable the movies were normally checked out with just a few left. Under normal conditions the odds are that you will find a movie that you like. Spa: We used the spa for the massages, steam bath, and sauna. We all thought the massages were good and everything was in good working order. They offer a lot of services. The only advice that I can give is to schedule as soon as possible because they fill up. Crowds: I never felt crowded at all. We did not have to stand in line to do anything. There were a few times when we had to wait for the concierge but that is to be expected. I never felt like I had to save our chairs but, as I mentioned, we did save only to make sure we could sit together. We did not have to wait in line to go to the restaurants or make reservations. Staff: Very accommodating and friendly. At times there was a language barrier but it was much better than expected. Summary: There are a few kinks they need to work out. Mostly with communication about what they offer. I did navigate the computer to see what activities they offer (yoga, when the horses were on the beach, etc.) but there wasn’t anyone telling us about activities ever. Additionally, when I would ask the staff they all had different answers. It appears that there is a communication breakdown between the management and staff. I recommend this to someone who is looking for a beautiful resort and is a pool person (not an ocean person). HTR is a quiet and friendly resort.

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant stay”
Reviews.Author: cjt51
Reviews.Content: This was our second trip to Mexico, the prior one was to the Grand Cozumel about 4 years ago. We booked this trip online earlier in the year for $970 per person (3 persons paying, no extra charge for the toddler) for 7 nights including airfare on American Airlines from Chicago. Our two children, ages 11 and 1 were with us on this trip. We called a couple of times, one week and one month prior to arrival asking that our room be on the ground floor, to be in the same building as our friends, and that the room include a crib. The person on the phone indicated that our requests would be honored. We pre-arranged transportation from the airport to HTR with Exeltur . The ride cost us $85 round-trip vs. most of the airport services wanting upwards of $90 for a one way ride. Our driver was waiting for us when we stepped out of the airport – the ride was about 40 minutes. We arrived at HTR around 1:00pm and wanted to get into our room so that we could unpack and feed our toddler. Instead, we were given a 20 minute presentation on the resort and how we could get other benefits if we attend a time-share sales presentation. We didn’t indicate any interest, and were never asked again. We were shown our room, but it was on the third floor in a new building that smelled heavily of organic chemicals. The room didn’t have a crib, but looked nice. It was apparent that we were the first ones to stay in that room – workers were still cleaning construction dust from the hallways. We insisted upon a ground-level room and ultimately ended up next door to our friends. During the switch, I ran into another couple that also did not want to stay in the new building. They also happened to notice that the Jacuzzi in their room didn’t work. The rooms are nice and are well kept. There wasn’t much of a view from our balcony – but we didn’t mind staying on the first floor because we didn’t want the inconvenience of having to take the elevator every time we stepped out. We requested a crib for our infant, but none arrived. It took some persistence and the crib arrived – about 3 hours after our initial request. It seemed like the staff was a bit stretched. The pools were nice, we enjoyed them every day. There was a bit of a battle for some of the poolside beds and there was a shortage of towels one day. But those were the only problems. Other reviews mention that poolside drink service was weak. Apparently, this has been corrected. Someone stopped by at least twice an hour asking if we wanted anything. Tipping a dollar or two for each order appeared to keep the staffs’ attention. One day, we ventured to Playa Del Carmen. We shared a taxi ride with our friends. A 12 passenger van cost us about $20 each way. The town was great fun. I recommend visiting in the late afternoon when the street artists are there. During our stay, we visited the plant nursery and cinotes (rivers). The bike tour was fine – it’s about 30 minutes of biking. The bikes could use some better maintenance. The nearby rivers and wildlife provided our 11 year old and his friends with plenty to do. It was great for them to see all sorts of wildlife. The children also enjoyed canoeing in the river that is in the middle of the resort. The resort had a few Hobie Cat sailboats that were available for use – but they only allowed them to be used when the water was flat. We used them a couple of times. Internet in the rooms was available, but it seemed to not respond a few times each day. I wouldn’t rely on it if you need to provide support while on vacation. The TV didn’t work 6 of the 7 days in our room – though we were able to see that the TVs worked in other rooms. We reported this, but it didn’t get fixed. No big deal – we didn’t go there to watch TV anyway. The water at the beach in front of the resort is filled with brown algae. Not appealing. There are other nicer beaches down the coast at other properties. One day, we hired a van from Exeltur for a day trip to Tulum. 5 hours of service cost $150. The concierge at HTR said that the same service would cost $200 (through another company) if we ordered it through them. The tour of Tulum was good. We purchased admission with a guided tour. Total price with the shuttle ride for 5 was $73. I recommend getting there as early as possible because it is a popular location with tourists. We arrived at 10:00am and it was already getting busy. I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of food. HTR food is comparable to Club Med’s, or even better. They have ala carte service at their Grill restaurant. Every entre we tried at the Grill was great. The drink service was good – though somewhat inconsistent. The bartenders would suggest drinks if you wanted to try something new. We stayed over Christmas week and asked Oscar, the executive chef, whether he could arrange a traditional ethnic Christmas Vigil (meatless) dinner. He agreed and we couldn’t of been more pleased. Oscar went a bit overboard, and prepared a 12 course meal. I wouldn’t of believed it if I didn’t see it. I just wish that we asked for 4 courses instead of the traditional 12. We made sure to tip the wait staff and the mariachi band that entertained us. The resort arranged for live entertainment during a beach party, similar to an evening luau. There was also live entertainment on Christmas Eve in the center of the resort. The staff also seemed to enjoy the opportunity to dance and celebrate with the clientele. None of us were sick during the trip – even though we had drinks with ice and drank the water poured at the tables. My sense is that their filtration system works well. Staff restocked the refrigerator in the room each day with soda, beer and water. Yes, drinking straws are somewhat rare at the resort – they claim to be eco friendly and can provide a paper drinking straw. That doesn’t explain the heavy disposable plastic stirrers that are placed into each drink. It seems like a plastic straw would use less plastic and could also serve as a stirrer. We are looking forward to another stay at this resort.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and Relaxing”
Reviews.Author: CaribCruiser116
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful, relaxing time. Weather was good for most of the days. We lost cable after our third day and never got it back. It didn't bother me but it did bother my husband a little. We were up most days at 7 AM to claim a bed on the beach and that is where I spent my time ! We were "present" on the bed, unlike many others that had items on the beds(reserving them) and then never bothered to show up until noon, which is not fair to other people who could be using the bed from 7 am on..... We had dinner at the "Chef's Table" and it was wonderful ! Oscar is a great chef and we were very impressed with our dinner. Arturo (Wine person) was also very accomodating. As another poster said, "communication was lacking between the staff" though. No one seemed to know exactly what activities were being held and where. We missed 20 minutes of a cooking demonstration because no one knew where it was. Asking different employees, you'd get different answers from each one. Activities, special dinners, etc. should be posted daily in the lobby then there would be no question what is going on and where they are being held. Maybe more people would be in attendance at these demonstrations. The mole demonstration (which was wonderful) was attended by me and my husband. All the prep work for this demonstration only to have two people attend ? The ocean was not as pretty as we hoped it would be. Not blue...more gray. Weather and all the rivers flowing around contributed to it. The beach was nice but nothing spectacular. It was relaxing to spend all day by the ocean though and be in warm weather ! We had many staff waiting on us and taking care of us, even calling us by our names...making sure we were being pampered. To mention a few...Angel (at breakfast and the beach), Elva (restaurant), the bartender in the Mexican restaurant (can't remember name), the bartender and attendants at the outdoor grill and also the wood-fired pizza oven. The rooms are spacious and beautiful, with a wonderful view of the ocean. The bathroom set up was really nice with the walk-in shower on one side and the spacious sink area. We went to the sauna and steam room. They were not upscale and one sauna room was out of order. We were a little disappointed with the quality and appearance but it served the purpose. It looked like it was added "after the fact" of building the resort. It's not up to standard with the rest of the resort amenities. Maybe in their future expansion they will build a more luxurious spa. Overall, it was a very nice vacation. We may return there at some point but we would like to check out other places around Playa Del Carmen also. It was a nice place to be and we were very pleased with the service and the food.

Reviews.Title: “Hacienda nice hotel but awful timeshare hosts.”
Reviews.Author: hosedragger
Reviews.Content: Hopefully I can make just one other person aware of a terrifying experience my wife and I went through on our vacation to Cancun. I hope just one other person sees this and turns the timeshare sales person down at the Cancun airport. This all started a few minutes after we got off the plane at the Cancun airport and were looking for our van to take us to our resort. A gentleman approached us and started offering event tours almost free with of course the exception of $45 up front. All you have to do is eat an incredible breakfast and go on a 90 minute tour. Well, i figured if I could save a few bucks on an event it may be worthwhile. BAD IDEA!!!! What I didn't realize was if you can't afford to buy into this timeshare you will absolutely be harassed and put under soo much pressure you will feel like that is your last day on earth and you may not get out of there alive. I will hopefully make one person's vacation much better than if they were to waste their time with a salesperson at the airport and spending half your day traveling to this 'Hacienda" resort, going on a 3+ hour tour, which was supposed to be 90 MINUTES and then if it isn't financially possible to afford the payments to try and explain that to at least three different high pressured sales individuals who absolutely will not take "NO" for an answer. Still, after a few weeks my wife is upset with what I made her go through by signing up for this AND actually giving cash up front at the airport. Just to maybe save a buck for an event I wanted to do. This place is situated back a mile and a half from the main road winding through a jungle lined with security folks and what appeared to be machine guns which made us skeptacle from the beginning. After we toured the "very nice hotel" we told two sales reps, one a "manager" it was a very nice place but we couldn't afford it. They kept coming back with other less expensive options which we found them still too expensive for our budget. We were then bought back to a man who made us go into a closed room and "drilled" us on why we couldn't afford any of these. He also gave us a few other options which just didn't seem appealing. We thought for sure we were going to die there and I was thinking of telling them I would buy something just to be let out alive. Finally, after another 15 minutes of him questioning us soo rudely and making my wife tear up they refused to shake my hand and sent us to pick up our promised event tickets. At that point neither of us cared about any "gift" and just wanted to get out to the main road where we could at least take a cab back to our hotel. We wasted a whole morning and most of an afternoon and were both ready to cry. As it turns out they did give us a few "event" tickets we were promised, however, transportation to the event tour one+ hour away was also promised by the airport salesperson but wasn't included and a "fee" was added to each ticket which was never explained. Basically if we were to have gone on the "event" we were promised it would have cost us more for the transportation to get there and the"fees" that it would have been better to get tickets for an event tour at our hotel and get transportation.They eventually did get a driver to drive us back to our hotel and he was very nice and actually offered us some good information. I do thank him for being soo nice to us. Very unfortunate this all took place the day after we arrived in Cancun as it really took the wind out of our sails for most of the week as we were both shaken from the experience. I guess even at my "old" ripe age I am still learning things but I will NEVER get myself into that kind of mess again. Basically, I did get a free very good breakfast...which I could've gotton at my hotel because it was 'all inclusive" anyway, and I did tour the Tres Rios Hacienda resort which could be potentially appealing and affordable to some people. However, if you think there may be a possibility you can't accept their offers, please, please stay away and save your vacation. -glad to be alive

Reviews.Title: “Great Place to stay!”
Reviews.Author: bw_klein
Reviews.Content: This was our 4th resort we stayed at along the Mayan Riveria, 2 south of Playa Del Carmen and 2 north of Playa Del Carmen. First time over Christmas. The resort was clean and beutiful. The service was above and beyond, the food, by far the best we have ever had, steak, pizza, buffet, all was absolutly great. Turkey on Christmas eve. Very tasty, never once got sick of buffet food, can't say enough about it. Chef Oscar tremendous job and very friendly and out going. As was all the staff, very friendly, curtiouse and helpful. Close to Playa for shopping (free shuttle there and back). Rooms nice and big and clean.TV went out second day there and never worked whole stay.(did not miss it) Lots to do at resort, bike tour, fresh water rivers to kahak, snorkel in. Cenote to snorkel in. Beach was great. Only thing wrong was the ocean was not the nicest, dirty water from teh Mangrove trees, still swam in it, kids played in it every day just not nice blue like othe resorts. One other thing is communication there was lacking, was not aware of some activities that where gong on even when we asked the concierge he could not tell us. Over all great resort, would go back for another stay. Bartman AB, CAN.

Reviews.Title: “A slice of paradise - We'll be back”
Reviews.Author: elMarcodeChicago
Reviews.Content: Vacations are important. They are an investment of time and money to improve you (and your family’s) physical and mental well being. So the last thing you want is problems and distractions that create stress, which is what you are going on vacation to get away from in the first place. One of the best places my family and I have found to relax without any worries was at Hacienda Tres Rios in Mexico’s Riviera Maya, south of Cancun and north of Playa del Carmen. This is a magnificent all-inclusive resort. The staff understands why its guests are there and that is to relax and be pampered. And we were! My family of two adult and two children visited the week of Christmas 2009. The staff said the hotel was entirely booked, but it never seemed crowded and the staff never seemed so busy as to decrease their attention to you. Yes, the resort is beautiful. Two large pools occupy the center: one more quiet, one more activity oriented. The famous king-sized canopy beds line the spotless beach allow for total relaxation. The crystal clear rivers, flowing from the cenotes to the ocean, provide a wonderful and calm place to swim or search for aquatic wildlife. The marble-lined suites are spacious and roomy. But I think what makes this resort stand head and shoulders above the others we’ve visited is the staff. They honestly go out of their way to make sure you are pleased. We found them so friendly that we learned their names very quickly. From Miguel, the catamaran captain, to Tony and Andy, the sports and activities directors, to Justino, Angel, Trinidad and Elva, the waiters, to Abernathy, the beach barman, to Nancy, the buffet restaurant hostess, to Hector, the concierge. Their politeness and eagerness made us feel totally at ease and free from stress during our stay. All of this customer-pleasing behavior is epitomized by the famous Oscar, the resort’s executive chef. As it was our first Christmas Eve – a major family holiday for us – we asked Oscar if it was possible to whip up some non-meat dishes to reflect our traditional Polish Christmas Eve dinner. Our family and our friends were blown away by the culinary glory we were served! Including a personalized birthday cake for our friends. Another family from Toronto, at the same dinner, were served a totally vegan dinner that they were singing the praises of. In fact, every meal we had was delicious. The outdoor grill became our favorite lunch spot, while the young boys in our group loved heading to the outdoor brick pizza oven or ordering plates of nachos. There’s a kids club but our boys preferred to be on their own and enjoyed the pool, playing water polo, or volley ball or soccer with the other guests under the direction of Tony and Andy. The evening entertainment is also well done, from the welcoming Mexican Fiesta, with mariachis, to the Mayan and Fire shows, to the Caribbean Party on the beach. There was also a Christmas Eve party in the main “square” of the resort, with live music and dancing. The resort tours to the cenotes are also worth booking, and because space is limited and there are many guests, they do fill up. However, we were still able to change our tours on Tuesday for Wednesday and Thursday without problem. However, our lackadaisicalness in booking a massage meant we couldn’t get one. Not a big deal. We visited Playa del Carmen’s famous 5th Avenue on a cloudy day by booking a taxi for $26 roundtrip and booked a taxi that took us to the ruins in Tulum, though there is an outside tour desk that will arrange tours for you. When it came time to leave, check out was at 11 am and our taxi was arriving at 2:30 pm. So we sat on the beach while our luggage was securely stored and when it was time to leave, we were given a courtesy room to change into our travel clothes. It’s those little things that you appreciate because it’s one less thing to worry about. And we certainly didn’t worry about anything while we stayed at Hacienda Tres Rios. We’ll be back. The only negative came from an intolerant guest, who felt the need to payback his hosts’ hospitality by stealing the baby Jesus statue from the outdoor Nativity display.

Reviews.Title: “Our Home Away From Home”
Reviews.Author: theasheart
Reviews.Content: We went the day after the news declared Mexico the epicenter for the Swine Flu. Our family spent 10 days amongst happy travelers from all around the world who enjoyed Hacienda Tres Rios luxury surroundings, warm staff, and a plethora of fun activities. Ecology: The ecological hotel offers clean drinking water throughout, including the showers, and recycles everything. There are three fresh water cenotes amongst the many acres of seclusion, and a free tour to learn about the ecology of the place and their conservation efforts. Food: The food is superb with three restaurants: one restaurant catering to traditional cuisine of the Maya, another for Italian and yet one more for everything under the sun. Fresh pizzas made to order by the pool in a brick oven, and every evening, petit edibles offered in their French cafe. You will get fat from the attentive pool staff who offer fresh treats and any drink you can think of – with alcohol or not. Surroundings: The interior is grand, luxurious and awaiting you is a warm towel, respectful staff and a glass of champagne. Spa: Excellent spa and daily fitness classes including Yoga, Pilates as well as Mountain Biking, canoeing, etc. Luxury at its best! Our favorite place to stay and reconnect.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing service and beautiful resort!”
Reviews.Author: karebear1018
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at HTR for about a week in November. We were there to attend a destination wedding with about 50 guests. Unfortunately it rained every day of our trip, however, we still had a great time since we spent our vacation with great friends at a nice resort. We could not have been happier with the service. From day 1, the staff made us feel very welcome and were extremely accommodating. We really enjoyed the food and the top shelf alcohol. The plate presentation at dinner was always amazing, especially the platescapping of the desserts. We also took advantage of the on site activities and enjoyed the cenotes and kayaking as well as the Sense tour, casino night and dance lessons. They also did an excellent job for setting up the wedding ceremony and reception that we attended. We had a blast!

Reviews.Title: “Great kids programming, fantastic staff, eco-orientation a plus”
Reviews.Author: StuckOnThePlane
Reviews.Content: We stayed at HTR with our kids (daughter, 8 and son, 5.5) in December 09 and were particularly pleased with the kids' programming -- Silvia and other staff were warm, inviting, and made our kids comfortable right away. Our son -- usually fearful and a bit of a homebody -- was almost as eager to attend as our older daughter, and they both had a great time. The entire staff (without exception) is genuinely polite, considerate, and charming -- really amazing service all around. We also appreciated the eco-tourism orientation: geothermal a/c and hot water, mangrove reforestation, and beach-scum harvesting for compost are all very appealing to us, as are the cenotes, kayaking, and unusually prolific wildlife. Finally, here's a brief example of the all-around service experience: I capsized a sailboat in rough wind and sea, and instead of being surly and rude the beach attendant sailed out on a second boat, let me hop over and sail in while he righted the other boat, and then actually took the time to teach me how to right a catamaran and explained exactly why I had capsized. We will most definitely return to HTR.

Reviews.Title: “Not Impressed Already....will not stay”
Reviews.Author: stueyman
Reviews.Content: After reading some reviews and checking this place out, I sent 2 emails to the resort asking very simple questions on the amenities, pools etc.. Never received a reply to either. Sent same emails to Sunset Hotels, who own the place, and never hear back in regard as well. I don't know what the problem is or what the secrets are here but I do know we will not even consider staying here. If the service is bad already, I can just imagine what it would be on site and not willing to chance it.

Reviews.Title: “Great staff, beautiful hotel”
Reviews.Author: MiddleRiver
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful 4 night vacation. The staff, without exception, were wonderful. All were friendly and helpful. The rooms were extreme luxury, with marble, fine linens and towels, stocked fridge, turndown service, 24 hour room service, etc. We are nature lovers and came to explore the "tres rios" and cenotes. There are many included nature tours (with usually only 2-6 people). The paths are well-maintained to allow exploring on your own as well. We kayaked early every morning and enjoyed the many birds. We came prepared with bug spray, but there were NO mosquitos. The pools are huge and beautiful. The beds on the beach are relaxing. Enjoy unlimited plush towels without signing for them or giving your room key or any such nonsense. Enjoy happy cocktail and food service delivered to your lounge chair. As noted in other reviews, the ocean is NOT inviting. It appears that organic matter, that looks like peat moss, washes from of the mangrove swamps, out through of the rivers and into the ocean. The waves then pulverize this material and this leads to muddy-appearing beach water. If you want to play in the ocean, this is not the place for you. On the other hand, they rivers themselves are clear and snorkeling is possible in the small rivers and some of the cenotes. The food is OK. Neither the buffets nor the a la cartes were great, but overall, the food was OK. The staff is happy to try to be accommodating. The 7-course meal at the chef's table was the exceptionally good meal. We had this on our last night and would recommend it. The bars were well-stocked and the service was very good. Food safety: we had not even a hint of intestinal distress. We did not drink tap water (there is bottled water in the rooms), but we had water in the restaurants and even had sushi. A word about time-share sales. Our welcoming concierge gave us the welcoming overview of the resort and then mentioned the gifts we would receive for taking a sales tour. We told her we were not interested, and we were not approached again regarding sales. We continued to have happy, friendly service. The resort could not have been 25% full on our visit. Positives: no waits for seating in any restaurants; easy to relax. Negatives: full buffets were set up for a handful of people, so the food turnover may not have been frequent - we went for mostly cook-to-order food; not a rocking place for the younger set. So, in summary, come here for relaxation, pampering, and nature. Thoughts about the future: The resort as it stands now is on the south side of the southern of 3 rivers. The middle and south rivers both begin in cenotes and flow to the ocean. They can be kayaked and snorkled. The northern river is actually more of a mangrove estruary with lots of shallow branching waterways. The master plan for the site includes another resort between the two southern rivers. It also appears that the northern mangrove estruary is to be replaced by a marina and several single family homes with docks. The consequences for birds and fish may be significant. It remains to be seen if this development stays true to the eco-friendly theme that is in place now. We hope so.

Reviews.Title: “The BEST trip ever!”
Reviews.Author: CK4SAGE
Reviews.Content: We took our young kids and they had a GREAT time and so did the adults! The staff was excellent!

Reviews.Title: “one of the best in ALL of Mexico!!”
Reviews.Author: debandben
Reviews.Content: We stayed there nov 8 to 12th. We wish it could have been longer, next time it will be. Others have stated things that we agree 100%. The food is great, I mean top notch. I normally have a dislike for buffets, but at Tres Rios, they do it in such a fashion, that the presentation is fantastic. The al carte menu's are to die for. The drinks are top shelf, if you want Grey Goose for example, you get it. Hector, at the front concierge desk is the BEST. He knows everything, just ask him anything. We did do a time share presentation and it was low pressure. At any time we could have left. As it turned out, we did buy. No regrets. The rooms were modern, clean, and very nice. We had a studio unit, more than enough room for two of us. Next year we are planning to come back with family. We have been to Cancun, Mazatlan and Puerto Vallarta. They all have their good points. In the Mayan area, it would be the lush tropical jungle. Playa Del Carmen is a fun place to visit for the day, great shopping on 5th ave. I hope this helped anyone who is trying to decide on a great place to stay while in the Mayan area.

Reviews.Title: “Great service.... but too much empasis on selling timeshares”
Reviews.Author: PMD1037
Reviews.Content: My wife and I recently spent 4 days at the resort for her birthday. The resort itself was OK, the pools were typical of a nice resort, the beach and especially the water were terrible... not anything like the blue waters of the carribean and other beachy resorts. The people that work there are EXCEPTIONAL, truly better than any resort or cruise we have been on. Hector was very good at keeping us informed and making suggestions. Unfortunately, since it rained the whole time we were there we spent a lot of time inside where we constantly encountered sales pitches all around us in the lobby, in the restaurants , etc. for their time share sales. We were called 4 times in our room asking if we wanted to attend. It seemed that we were the only regular guests there at times. As others have said, Oscar isgreat. He even has a secret dining venue in the kithen which we happened to find out about from another couple. why no one from the resort told us, i don't know. I can only speculate that it had to have to do with them selling timeshares and making this dining exoerience a perk. Overall an Ok resort with and incredible staff

Reviews.Title: “Terrific new resort in the Riviera Maya”
Reviews.Author: toorelaxed
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Hacienda Tres Rios for 4 nights in October. As a travel agent, I won the four nights at a tradeshow. We stayed in a room with jacuzzi on the balcony with views of the pool, river and ocean. Resort was beautiful, about 30 minutes from Cancun airport. The resort was not crowded except for a large wedding party for a couple of days, but overall it was very quiet. The service was top notch. Pool and beach service was a plus. Drink orders and food orders brought right to you. Oscar, the executive chef was always around, making himself available to answer questions and just a very personable gentleman. Everyone in the resort was friendly and always made you feel welcome and there was not anything they could not do for you. Drinks were plentiful. Food was very good. I thought the Italian was superb. Also ate outside under the stars and the meal was delicious as well as the sax player which added a very nice ambiance. Don't be afraid to ask for something you may not see on the menu, as they always try to accommodate you. One day they came around the pool with crackers with fresh tuna on them as an appetizer. The next day I saw Oscar and asked if there was any more of it and he asked how I wanted it (on what kind of bread) and had it delivered to me at the pool. Also, one day asked the server at the pool if they had any shrimp and within minutes they brought plates full of grilled shrimp which were delicious! Pools were very nice and relaxing. We stayed at the adults pool most of our stay. Was very relaxing and they play beautiful music so you can still read and relax. The beach is very nice with beds along the beach that are very comfortable. I found the water to be a bit murky and had a lot of seaweed in parts of it. Facing the water from the beach, further down to the left the water was clearer and less seaweed. I found the bottom in the water a bit "mushy". I did swim in the river closest to the sea and the water was crystal clear and very refreshing. I did not indulge in the "cenotes". Pretty much just vegged out at the pool or on the beach beds. Very quiet at night. Would not recommend this resort if you are looking to party the night away. I would recommend this resort very highly. If you are looking for excellent food, beautiful accommodations, great service, friendly warm staff, average beach, very nice pool atmosphere, quiet an a bit upscale, this is the place for you to consider. Any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me. Anthony

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Trip to Tres Rios”
Reviews.Author: KamryncatNB
Reviews.Content: Well our first trip to Mexico. We arrived at the airport, what a zoo. Make sure that you have transportation arranged before you arrive, that way you won't be scammed into some sort of timeshare presentation. We met our family at the meeting place and found our van service and off we went. I was surprised to see so much destruction and garbage along the way. I assumed that 5 years after Wilma things should have been completed and cleaned up. In Canada we have a recyle program for bottles and cans, no word of a lie there were literally thousands of them along the road. We arrived at Tres Rios, the drive in from the main road felt peaceful and serene. It wound around all the mangroves, trees and fawna. It felt like it had always been there and not a new resort. Upon our arrival the bell boys greeted us took our luggage and directed us to check in. There were greeted with a lovely green juice, which is celery, pinapple and parsley. Fantastic! Very cooling, also they had cool faceclothes with a hint of lemon for us. Check in was smooth, and the girl at the front desk was very friendly. We were then directed to the lobby to wait for one of the girls, she came over and explained what was were, and what tours were available and also to offer you a timeshare presentation. Shikra then took us to our room and showed the room to us, it was on the second floor. 2 bedroom that sleeps 8. OMG! Bathrooms are floor to ceiling Marble, all floors are marble. Ok so where do I start, the main sitting area has a couch and chair, flat screen TV, touch screen panel to order things like room service, turn down service ect... We used that several times trying to order room service and it didn't seem to be working, we asked several times and then finally when the waiter came he advised that that service was not working. Mini Bar also in this room stocked daily with water, pop and beer. There was also a full bathroom in this area. Also you can go out to the balcony from here with sliding doors. This balcony goes acroos this unit and connects with the masterbed room. Only has 2 chairs. If you open the doors the AC goes off. That is a really nice feature so that you are not wasting power. Masterbed room... King size bed, and boys it was comfortable, falt screen TV, Whirlpool tub and another couch. Patio doors out to the balcony. Only down part of this is only 2 chairs on the deck, the unit is for 8. If we all wanted to sit out we had to drag out chairs from in side. Our bathroom was huge! The dressing area had a great size closest, bank of drawers and 2 sinks and a sit down area for applying makeup ect.. The toilet was in a room off of this all by its self and the shower was off of this as well and was huge, it also had a clothesline for hanging things to dry. NIce. The second bedroom was a fantastic size as well. 2 full size beds, flat screen, mini bar, couch, bathroom and patio doors out to their own private balcony. Again on this one there are 2 chairs and small table. All of the units face the water. They all have a lovely view of the river around the property, the pool area and the ocean. It is a must to get up early at least one morning and watch the sunrise and listen to the sounds of the birds. Amazing! There are several restaurants, a la carte and buffet. There are two buffet restaurants for breakfast, make sure you get to the Mexican buffet for breakfast it is really quite lovely. The Grill for lunch is the best. Samuel is wonderful, you will see him around all the time, from early morning to late evening. If they don't have it ask and they will get it. There was an Italian, Thai, Steak and Mexican a la carte restaurants, there was a Mexican welcome party and a caribbean beach party. Portions were small as with any fine dining experience. I really feel that the food was just a little pretentious. Also we enjoy alot of flavour. Garlic, spices, hot etc... Some of the foods seemed a little bland. We spoke with Oscar and my friend mentioned this to him, and he explained that Mexican food isn't all hot and spicey, he mentioned to ask for his food spicey and they would do that for him. Other friends of ours where staying there and didn't see Lasagna on the menu and ask Ocsar for it and he had the chefs make it form them. Very accomodating. Hector at the concierge was FANTASTIC! He knew everything about anything we wanted to do, I wish I could have packed him in my suit case and brought him home. There is also a coffee bar. I would highly recommend it. If Antonio is there have him make the specialty coffe for you. What an experience. The waiting staff is truly amazing. They tend to every need. They are always there ready at an moment for any request. Alfredo in the Italian Reastaurant was fab.... Fansisco in the Martini Bar was awsome, ask him for the chocolate mint martini...Yum! Head of the activities I believe is Roberto, and Serigo! I love these two so much they made our stay fantastic. There are the best! AAA+ The only negative thing that we found other then not having Orange Pekoe Tea, which if there are a lot of Canadians travelling there this would be a necessity, was consistency. If we found something that we liked to eat and ordered it again, it was never the same thing. Room service never brought everything that we ordered. We ordered everyday and there was always something missing or the wrong thing sent. For instance were ordered 2 apple juice and 2 orange juice they sent sliced apples and oranges, just small things. I'm sure with more time things will smooth out. Somethime it was clearly a language barrier. Our mini bar was fully stocked but by the end of the week they were only leaving 2 bottles of water and that was it. Beach....Pools Pools are fabulous, the pool near the grill was the adult section. Lots of sunbeds and umbrellas. Service at the pool was great and fast. Fernando and Carlos were the best. As far as tipping, we always tip, however at the end so really it doesn't affect your service whether you tip or not. Down at the beach they have lovely four poster canopy beds. We went in the water once while we were there they are still trying to clean the water area. I must say if you want to swim in the ocean go a little to the right and swim there. We swam at the beach area and we ended up getting stung, by what we are not sure because the water is murky looking in that area. If you get a chance to do the Cenotes, I would highly recommend it. We seen a turtle. We didn't get to them all due to the amount of rain that came during the week. We will definitely go back to this resort, the service and staff out way the little things that weren't consistant..

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort and Outstanding Service”
Reviews.Author: traveler2828
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Hacienda Tres Rios from October 31st to November 7th 2009. In our group was myself, my wife and my son who is 13 years old. We were in a two bedroom suite. This suite is one two bedroom suite away from the end of the southern building, closest to the ocean and on the top floor. This suite also had a spiral staircase going up from the balcony to a wooden terrace on the roof. Nothing was on this terrace, but we were told that some terraces have a jacuzzi. It was a good view all the same and also quite private. The rooms were quite luxurious as pictured on their website and in pictures posted by tripadvisor members including pictures by myself. This is by far the nicest resort I've ever been in. It's design is slightly more Mexican than many other resorts and was meant to be that way. I guess the more modern resort they plan to build on the Tres Rios site to the north will be less Mexican inspired design and more westernized and modern than Hacienda Tres Rios. They are still doing construction on the final building on the north side of the resort. I was told that this should be done by sometime in December. They were also doing some minor construction at the pool area closest to the resort. Not sure what they were doing there. We were also told that once this construction finishes they will connect the circular water feature inside the resort ground with the external water in the jungle and swamp. This will clear up the water and after that they plan to start up the gondola rides on the circular water feature. None of this construction impacted our enjoyment of the resort, in fact, unless you went looking, you rarely noticed it. They are also working on and finishing up the first La Herencia which is a building with one, two and three bedroom units with jacuzzis on the roof, kitchens in the units, basically fully functional luxury condos. There is planned to be more, but I do not know the number. These include butler service and personal chef service. They even provide storage so you can decorate the condo suite as you like it while you're there and when you leave, they will store it for you and put everything back as you had it when you come back. It's quite expensive to buy in for one month minimum, but if you want this level of service, I guess it's worth it. At this time there were two primary indoor food locations one on the lowest floor and one on the next floor up typically accessed from an elevator just to the right of the concierges. Just push the R button in the elevator to get to the restaurant. The bottom floor is called the PB floor and the next floor up is called the 1st floor and so on to the 3rd floor which is the highest floor in the resort. Starting at 7:00 am, the restaurant on the PB floor becomes Casas Las Islas with buffet breakfast and lunch. Lunch starts at approximately noon. At 7:00 pm this restaurant is transformed either into Porto Bella (Italian) or Katori (Asian Fusion). Which restaurant varies and it's not a simple change from one day to the other. Check the console in the room to see what the restaurant schedule is when you arrive. At this restaurant if you want something other than the house wines, you can select from a wine rack for an extra charge beyond the all inclusive charge. The restaurant upstairs on the 1st floor accessed via the elevator is a Mexican buffet in the morning nominally opening at 7:00 am but really getting things ready for 8:30 am when the sales team brings potential buyers for breakfast to that restaurant. The second sales tours start at 9:30 am. We never ate lunch indoors although it was available but we either ate at the outdoor restaurants or ordered room service. The outdoor restaurants are the Hacienda Grill which serves sandwiches and entrees and the Pizzeria Il Forno. I liked the chicken stuffed with ham and cheese at the Hacienda Grill and the pizza was good at the Pizzeria Il Forno but the calzone I had was too doughy although quite acceptable. They only have sweetened iced tea not unsweetened ice tea at the indoor restaurants. I liked almost everything I had although I am sure there would have been things on the menu I wouldn't have liked, but that is true at almost any restaurant. Whether you like something is a personal thing. I also liked the pig or pork dish in the Mexican Restaurant, Alebrije, served in the evening. This is also where you can get the cricket appetizer which is also good. My son cut it open so he could see the cricket and so after that he refused to eat it. My wife liked the Salmon dish on the room service menu and I liked the chocolate cake alot and the Tiramisu less so also on the room service menu. The Patisserie Cafe de Paris is indoors and opens at teatime nominally 3:00 pm although it wasn't always open when I thought it would be open. They have small sweets and also small single or two bite sandwiches. They have gourmet coffee there and also claim to have tea but if you order tea there, they fetch it from the main restaurant, Casas Las Islas. The Sports Bar is also indoors but only serves drinks, no food. They do have activities at the Sports Bar. This is where you play Jenga or use the pool-table or the XBox. They also have flat screen TVs in there if my memory serves me correctly. According to representatives of the resort, there will eventually be 9 total food and drink locations. One will be a deli or a sandwich shop quite likely and both Porto Bella and Katori will have separate locations and will be available every day. This may happen as early as sometime in December. This should improve the already great restaurant selections. Since this is also construction related, we also got an update on their plans for a onsite scuba shop and tour operator. They are in negotiations with a sponsor to build the scuba shop and perhaps even staff it. The scuba boat will be based at the pier. It is probably six months to a year out, but that is my speculation. I also found out that they are planning on building a zip line in the jungle but that is also six to eight months out and is still in the active planning stage. Also to show their eco focus, they've decided not to build a golf course which was in their original plans as it would cause too large an impact on the local environment even though they could have claimed it was a green feature. One really nice touch that some other all-inclusives don't do, is if you check out but you are still at the resort because your plane flight is late in the afternoon, you can still eat at the restaurants. The opening times of the restaurants is what I call on resort time, so even if they are supposed to be open, they may be only setting up and will not be opening for a while. We got caught in this. We ordered pizza as Casas Las Islas was delayed beyond their nominal opening time. The schedule for the activities is on their website www dot haciendatresrios dot com. I will repeat it here though for completeness and describe in more detail those we went on. They have yoga classes, meditation classes, stretching classes and pilates classes at 8:00 am and 9:00 am. The 8:00 am are in spanish and the 9:00 am are in english. At 9:30 am is the Bicycle tour and at 10:00 am is the Jaguar tour. At 11:00 am is Beach Volleyball near the beach area and at 12:30 pm are various activities. They are Flavors of Yucatan on Monday, Cocktail class Tuesday, Towels decoration Wednesday, Cocina Natura on Thursday, Fruit Carving on Friday and Sushi Class on Sunday. At 2:00 pm the tours alternate from the Tigrillo tour to the Coati tour. AT 3:00 pm they have Bocci Ball on Monday, Horse Shoes on Tuesday, Plant your Mangrove on Wednesday, Bocci again on Thursday, beach game or Friday and Horse Shoes again on Sunday. At 3:30 pm they have various activities once again. They are Wine Tasting on Monday, Tequila Tasting on Tuesday, Mole History on Wednesday, Water Polo on Thursday, Soccer on Friday and Soccer on Sunday. At 4:00 pm, on Monday they have a Massage demonstration, on Tuesday it's a Nursery tour, Wednesday Spanish class, Thursday Nursery tour, Friday Spanish class and Sunday Spanish class. On Saturday from approximately 12:30 pm on they have welcome briefings and continue on Sunday morning from 8:00 am until about noon. They tours schedule described above differ just a bit from the schedule they have posted online. We did the Tigrillo tour which involved going to Cenote Aguila where you can snorkel if you so choose for about 10 minutes. I snorkeled the Cenote Aguila. There are fish there including a small school of dark fish about 1 1/2 to 2 feet in length and some yellow striped fish just over a foot in length. Other fish were in there but they were smaller and not overly distinctive. I also saw a crab. The roots from the trees were cool too and you could see the underground tunnels where the water connects from cenote to cenote. After snorkeling, we got in the kayaks and paddled down near the beach area where we pulled out of the water onto a sandy beach area near the north side of the resort near the beach. If you do decide to snorkel make sure you reapply the mosquito repellant over your body as I didn't and received many mosquito bites while I kayaked from the cenote to the beach. The mosquitos are much worse during the rainy season which we were on the tail end of at the beginning of November. The difference from this tour and the Jaguar tour is that in the Jaguar tour you do the snorkeling at Cenote Aguila, kayak to the beach and then kayak up to the Cenote Tortuga. With the Coati tour you tour the Nursery and then swim and snorkel at Cenote Aguila. The Senseadventure tour isn't on the schedule but I believe it is at 11:00 am, 12:00 noon, 1:20 pm and 2:00 pm every day other than perhaps Saturday and/or Sunday. We went on this and it was very nice. You go blindfolded through much of this and I won't go into too much more detail other than saying it teaches you to trust directions, enhances all your other senses including touch, smell, taste, sound and puts you in a expansive state if possible for you. You also take the blindfold off for a short bit of a time. It's probably best if you go with someone close to you like a wife or husband but it's not absolutely necessary. It enhances peace and serenity as well. The Kids club includes a number of activities but my son mostly just utilized the XBox in the kids club during rainy periods. It rained a fair amount during our time at the resort but we had sun most days if only for a few hours. Monday was actually our best day with sun all day except for a brief shower at around about noon for about 20 minutes. The kids club splits the kids into age groups, 4-12 and 13 and up. I'm not sure about the minimum age but this is my recollection. All the employees were quite courteous, with "Hola", "Buenos Dias", "Buenos Tardes" and "Buenos Noche"s and even "Como Esta" if you showed any propensity to respond properly. They also sometimes utilized "de nada" as appropriate to "Muchos Gracias" or Thank you. Everyone seemed to want to help as much as they were able to. Part of the issue is finding the right person to ask to get the answer that you need. Most of the Concierges and desk people spoke good english and understood who knew what and where they were. Also Oscar, the head chef seemed to be in charge of the whole resort and sometimes stepped in to make sure the food order was right. He also responded to my in-laws request to turn down the volume of the music by the pool as my in-laws thought the music was too loud. We ordered room service quite a bit and one issue we discovered is the food sometimes comes luke warm. One interesting thing that I discovered is that you can request a microwave oven for your room at no charge and we did. It came in handy to warm up room service food that was not warm enough. There is also a small booth down near the pool closest to the beach where a vendor sells mostly hand made items. He can make somethings right there if you need it personalized. An example is my son wanted a bracelet but the bracelets on display didn't have his name so the vendor made it for him and it took about 20 minutes and he kept going even in the rain as it started raining shortly after we asked him to make it for our son. They also set-up a drink station at the pool near the beach. I think this was a response to the initial criticism of the time it took to get drinks while at the beach or the pools. The servers are now all over the area and usually come by more than often enough for me. Also, unusually for many resorts, they have one lifeguard who wanders around the beach and pool areas. This is more than most resorts in my humble opinion. In spite of this, at one point while I was in a pool a young girl with poor swimming skills jumped in the water to go after a ball that was floating in the pool. She was struggling to stay afloat and appeared to be flailing around in the water. I didn't see any parents anywhere nearby, so I lifted her and carried her to the edge of the pool and helped her get out. The pools are mostly 5 feet deep in most areas although they do have areas where you can sit in the water and not be fully in the water if you want that. The nightly entertainment was excellent. The Mayan Show was athletic and they did dances and acted out stylized hunts and played a simplified version of the Mayan ball game that turned into an athletic dance. The Fire Show was also quite nice and involves a number of in-shape and athletic men and women working flaming batons, sticks and other items. The Live Music night was nice with a band they brought in from the Dominican Republic if my memory serves me correctly. They played 40s music and latin music. I didn't stay too long as my wife went up with my son and I went up shortly afterwards but I heard a Salsa number before I left and people were dancing by then. I didn't participate in the Karaoke night or Casino night so I cannot say anything about them. We did check out the gym and they had elliptical machines which I like and some stationary bicycles and treadmill machines. They also had free weights and weight machines as well and a large Pilates yoga ball. The car rental is on the right in the corridor past the patisserie and Sports bar on the right. There is also an ATM there. The Spa and gym are past the Patisserie, the car rental booth and after going through glass doors you then go up one floor via an elevator or stairs that are on the right. They do have fairly easy to use Hoby Cat sailboats with minimal adjustments to make it easy for anyone not used to sailing catamarans to sail them. They had two working while we were there. They were working on some others so they should have more shortly. They also, obviously have kayaks. We were also told that in December, they plan to have some yachts tied up to the pier right at Hacienda Tres Rios, so guests will not have to travel to the Sunset Lagoon Resort in Cancun to rent yachts if renting a yacht is desired. The accomodations were very nice. We had a two bedroom suite. The master bedroom had a king size bed with a jacuzzi next to the window. The beds have pillow top mattresses and very nice pillows too. I would have liked a larger jacuzzi but that's me, perhaps not everyone would agree. They do provide a package of bath salts for the jacuzzi. The showers are quite nice and luxurious, the separate toilet area is nicely spare with a telephone on the wall and the bathroom area is quite big with storage in the form of a closet and drawers in that area as well. They provide soap, shampoo, conditioner, body wash, hair cap and a complementary sewing repair kit. In my wife's opinion, the built in hair dryer is underpowered and takes too long to dry hair as it's too weak a flow and perhaps not hot enough. They had a large flat screen TV with DVD player also in the master bedroom. There was also a sofa with pull out bed and coffee table. Two bedside tables were also there and a clock radio with an IPOD connection or standard stereo audio connection to an MP3 player. Two chairs and a small table were out on the balcony. A spiral staircase from the balcony in the Master Bedtroom went up to a roof-top wooden terrace with a great view and excellent privacy. In the living/dining room area, there is a large table for six and a sofa with pull out bed that our son used to sleep on. There was also a large flat screen TV in the living room but no DVD player and a dresser with shelves and drawers. A small coffee table was in that room and a chair separate from the dinner table furniture. There was no outdoor furniture on the balcony for that room but the balcony connects to the balcony for the master bedroom so that's not any problem at all. The bathroom in the living/dining section was smaller than the master bathroom but also had a nice shower although the toilet and sink were in the same room. The second bedroom was separated by doors that can be opened from both sides to connect the suites. We left them closed as our in-laws stayed there. Two coffee machines were in the suite. One in the second bedroom and one in the living/dining room. There were two queen sized beds in second bedroom, a sofa with pull out bed and a small table for two to eat at in that room as well. Sometimes a jacuzzi is out on the balcony in this room but there wasn't one in the room my in-laws stayed in although they had outdoor furniture there. The second bedroom also had it's own luxurious bathroom with a very nice shower just like all the other rooms and a underpowered hair dryer. The two pools were also very nice. One nice feature that isn't obvious is if you like swimming, the pool nearest the ocean has a very long linear area that you can swim a long way without turning around. You do have to curve just a bit, but that wasn't a problem for me or probably for just about anyone. I took a number of pictures of the resort and have posted them here on tripadvisor with this review and also some videos. We were very happy with everything and all the employees. Other than the weather we were very happy and the resort couldn't do anything about the weather. We can't complain as the last time we were in the Playa del Carmen area in early November 2008 the weather was gorgeous with just one short passing shower that I remember. There was a wedding party here this time and they had to move their ceremony in from the outside to the inside but they were still quite happy with the resort and accomodations and how they handled the wedding arrangements. On a side note, during our stay, the Maxim Girls showed up for a photo and video shoot and to do some sponsored activities like play volleyball, kick a soccer ball, play flag football and run an obstacle course. They enjoyed mixing with the other guests and seemed happy to have their picture taken with guests including our son. We heard that the photos will be in the Mexican edition of Maxim only. Feel free to contact me if you have any questions on this resort. If I know the answer, I will be happy to help you out. I really enjoyed this resort and vacation alot.

Reviews.Title: “If you don't like Tres Rios, don't bother leaving your house”
Reviews.Author: VirginiaNorm
Reviews.Content: This is a great property, with the perfectly trained staff, and best food I've ever experienced. My wife and I visited with our 28 year old son, and had a wonderful time. Of course, the fact that Maxim magazine was holding a photoshoot and competition for model of the year helped with the son's enthusiasm.The activies on the property are varied and abundant. Tip: sign up for the Chef's Table. You will eat at a table literally in the kitchen and receive a seven course meal served by the head chef, Oscar Sanchez.

Reviews.Title: “Really Nice Resort That Will Only Get Better- Travel Agent Review”
Reviews.Author: mad4travel_01
Reviews.Content: Hotel- Nice new hotel in a traditional style. Layout is good with nothing too far away. Flat screens in rooms and were just installing an interactive system in the rooms which will allow you to access concierge, make a wake up call, look at menus, order room service, etc. Found upon entering room there seemed to be a musty smell but believe it actually was a bio-degradable bug spray that was in room. Our room had a jacuzzi on the balcony. Wi-fi is accessible throughout the resort and also in the room, which is unusual. No connection problems. Resort is a green resort and gets its name from the 3 rivers that abut the resort and empty into the ocean. Ride in to the resort was interesting as you were surrounded by the mangroves and a lot of flora. Don't know if we went in by the wrong entrance as our driver had never been there before. Were greeted with cold towels and a pineapple/celery juice combination which they called green juice and was much better than it sounds. Resort is mostly complete but they were working on one wing while we were there. Noise was very minimal. Restaurants- Cafe Islas is the buffet area and only choice, besides room service, for breakfast. Also have afternoon and evening buffet there. Indoor. Good buffet with omelet/egg station and some interesting menu items. For a buffet was better than average. Traditional Mexican, Alibrije,is indoors and very colorful with very nice artwork. Buffet for lunch and ala carte for dinner. Very good food with some interesting dishes. My thoughts on all the specialty dining (although we did not try the Asian) was that the food was exceptional, approaching gourmet. European portions throughout. The real problem was the menu translation to English was very poor. They really need to hire someone to do this as sometimes the dish would come out and you were wondering what you thought you ordered. This notwithstanding, liked every item that I ordered and it actually became kind of funny. Did really like the Chipotle Creme Brule that we had here for dessert. Seemingly an odd combination but excellent. No reservations are required for the ala carte restaurants. Right now the Asian Fusion, Kotori, and the Italian ,Porto Bello, swap nights at the same area but we were told that the permanent home of Porto Bello is near completion. There is an outdoor pizza venue, Pizzeria Il Forno, that uses a wood burning brick oven, that is open in the afternoon. Pizzas were surprisingly good- had a wonderful 4 cheese pie. Also the Hacienda Grill, which is an outdoor venue near the pool area, and is open for lunch and dinner. Only had lunch here and again, excellent.
